DOC.HEAD: Italian Astrologers Predict Peace In The Gulf
DOC.TEXT: After peering into their crystal balls, Italian clairvoyants predict war tensions in the Persian Gulf will dissipate and President Mikhail Gorbachev will weather Soviet upheaval over the coming year. Don't celebrate yet, though. This is from the bunch that foresaw the failure of German unification. And not all that is augured is good. ``Europe will have to defend itself from an invasion of foreign workers and foreign investments and may have temptations of isolationism,'' wrote Lucia Alberti, an astrologer who prints a yearly calendar of events. Recession will be the major evil in most countries during 1991, she said. Most Italian members of the European Association of Clairvoyants predicted in newspaper accounts this week that not a single shot will be fired over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. But President Bush and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein may face assassination attempts, according to Bernardo Gandolfo, a Naples clairvoyant.

DOC.HEAD: Uganda Frees Italian Journalist, U.S. Priest
DOC.TEXT: The army has released an American priest and an Italian cameraman held for a week, after rebel fighters held the cameraman for two days. The cameraman, Giorgio Salomone, and the Rev. Joseph Bragotti, were freed Thursday by military authorities in Lira, 130 miles north of the capital, Kampala. The detentions came after Salomone was captured and held by guerrillas from Dec. 17-19 in northern Uganda, where he and another Italian journalist were working on a report about missionaries, Bragotti said. Braggoti, hometown unavailable, said they were not abused but that Salomone was asked to write three statements about what he saw during his abduction by the rebels. Braggoti, 53, said he had been in Uganda on vacation when he volunteered to assist the Italians in their film.

DOC.HEAD: Food Prices To Increase After New Year's
DOC.TEXT: The price of bread, sugar and rice will increase by about 30 percent in the new year as part of the government's austerity plan to get international loans, a newspaper reported. The Budapest daily Nepszabadsag, quoting managers at state food trading companies, said flour, cosmetics and other household goods also will increase. These are suggested retail prices; final prices will be determined by market conditions, the paper said. The increases are seen as necessary to revitalize industries whose traditional subsidies have been slashed by the government as it tries to qualify for credits from the International Monetary Fund. The state railroads announced earlier in December that domestic fares would increase by 80 percent and the national telephone company is planning a 150 percent hike in phone charges. Postal services are going up by 40 percent and municipal bus fares by 55 percent early next year.

DOC.HEAD: China Said to Continue Military Aid To Khmer Rouge, Despite Denial
DOC.TEXT: China is supplying new military aid to Cambodia's communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas, despite its claim to have halted shipments months ago, Western intelligence and other sources say. The sources also say the Cambodian government is receiving support from thousands of Vietnamese soldiers disguised as Cambodians. Vietnam says it has withdrawn all its troops, but the rebels have long disputed that. The reports emerged this week as peace talks were stalled between the Cambodian government and the resistance. Fighting has intensified in western Cambodia over the past month. The Khmer Rouge are loading ``trucks and trucks of new Chinese ammunition,'' said one Western intelligence official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``There is a recent increase in Chinese supplies to the Khmer Rouge.'' Other sources at the Thai border town of Aranyaprathet and elsewhere along the Cambodian frontier said this week that the Chinese are preparing fresh deliveries of ammunition in anticipation of a government offensive. China is the main backer of the Khmer Rouge and two other guerrilla groups fighting the government Vietnam installed after invading Cambodia in late 1978. The Khmer Rouge, which was ousted from power by the invasion, is the strongest guerrilla army. China said it had stopped military assistance after the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, including China and the United States, adopted a peace plan for Cambodia in late August. ``Since the five member countries of the Security Council adopted the five documents on Cambodia, China has not provided any military assistance, including weapons, to the Cambodian resistance,'' China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Li Zhaoxing, said last month. The guerrillas have supported the U.N. plan, which calls for a truce followed by U.N. involvement in the country's administration and U.N.-supervised elections. But the Vietnamese-installed government has rejected key elements of the plan. Meanwhile, government forces are preparing a major offensive in the approaching dry season, Western intelligence and guerrilla sources say. They say the government is supported by Vietnamese troops who have secretly returned to Cambodia disguised as Cambodian government soldiers. Vietnam says it withdrew all troops from Cambodia in September 1989. But Western intelligence sources in Bangkok say they believe there are 4,000 to 9,000 Vietnamese military personnel in the country. They say Vietnam has supplied large amounts of ammunition to the government in recent months. However, one analyst predicted that if peace talks break up, the Khmer Rouge is in a position to win the war. ``If the Phnom Penh government chooses to fight it out with the Khmer Rouge, they are making a big mistake,'' said the intelligence analyst in Bangkok. ``(Khmer Rouge) support within the country is growing, and they have the means to continue, regardless of any international cutoff. If this peace proposal fails, it is out of the control of anyone but Cambodians, and in the long run it is the Khmer Rouge who will win. During its rule from 1975-79, the Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodians directly through purges and executions and indirectly through starvation and the hardship of a radical agrarian relocation program.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Honorary Member of All-Male Club
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle doesn't abide discrimination at golf clubs, his office says, but he still plays at one of the most exclusive all-male courses near the capital as an honorary member. Quayle on Friday canceled a second round of golf at the all-white Cypress Point golf club near Monterey, Calif., after he learned the facility was mired in a racial controversy, said his press secretary, David Beckwith. He had played there Thursday, unaware, Beckwith said, that the club was ruled ineligible for its share of the 1991 AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am tournament next month because it has no black members. Quayle was ``unwilling to leave any impression that he condones any form of discrimination,'' so he left California and returned to Vail, Colo., where he had been on a skiing vacation, Beckwith said. But the spokesman said he could not explain why Quayle is an honorary member of the Burning Tree Club in suburban Bethesda, Md., which bars women from its course. ``He encourages all clubs to adopt non-discriminatory policies,'' Beckwith said. He said Quayle is not a ``dues-paying member.'' The club's membership roster lists him as an honorary member. Burning Tree's members include some of the nation's most powerful political leaders. The 68-year-old club last year lost a court battle to regain a tax break the Maryland legislature had revoked in 1986 because of its refusal to admit women as members or generally allow them on the property. Quayle's chief of staff, Bill Kristol said in a telephone interview, ``I don't think playing at Burning Tree is inconsistent with opposing discrimination. Lots of people with good anti-discriminatory records have played golf at Burning Tree.'' Cypress Point does admit women, but it refused to admit black members in time to conform to the Professional Golfers Association's new guidelines that hold no host tournament club can discriminate against blacks or women. ``We have no discrimination clauses in our bylaws, but we do not have black members,'' said club pro Jim Langley. ``We have a waiting list of approved applicants of several years, and we couldn't bypass them.'' Quayle went to Cypress Point at the invitation of his college roommate, Mark Rolfing, a media golf commentator, according to local sources. He teed off Thursday with two Cypress Point Club members who are administration officials - Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice, and Ebersole Gaines, the top U.S. diplomat in Bermuda. Beckwith said Quayle was assured the club had no policy of discrimination but left Friday because he did not want to leave any appearance of condoning discrimination. Asked how Quayle could be unaware of the highly publicized banning of Cypress Point from the PGA tournament, Kristol said: ``It proves he's not spending time reading the golf pages.'' The vice president leaves Washington tonight on a New Year's visit to U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf area.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Urges Observers at Indonesia Trials
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Sidney correct as woman's name
DOC.TEXT: Indonesia plans to try leaders of a little-known insurgent movement next month, and overseas human rights groups should monitor the trial, one of the groups says. About 40 defendants face charges in three cities for alleged activity in behalf of Aceh Merdeka, or Free Aceh, an armed liberation group operating at the northern tip of Sumatra, Sidney Jones, executive director of Asia Watch, said Friday. The cases could provide accounts of torture, killings and other atrocities that have become routine in counterinsurgency campaigns in the Aceh region and elsewhere in Indonesia, Asia Watch said. In Aceh, ``there is no question that both sides have engaged in atrocities, but the scale and brutality of the Indonesian response is out of all proportion to the threat posed by the insurgents,'' Ms. Jones said. The current outbreak of violence in the Aceh region began 18 months ago and the combined death toll on both sides has been estimated as high as 1,000, Asia Watch said in a year-end report on the situation. ``Corpses continue to be found along roads and rivers in three districts of Aceh,'' it said. The Indonesian military ``appears to have systematically killed at least dozens and perhaps hundreds of suspected Aceh Merdeka supporters in revenge, as a deterrent and as a means of disposing of prisoners.'' Human rights violations in the Aceh region ``fall into a pattern of systematic and gross abuses already well established in Indonesia,'' the report said. It cited similar abuses in past disturbances in East Timor, East Irian and Central Java. ``Torture techniques reported from Aceh occur throughout Indonesia, including in Jakarta police stations ... torture reported from Aceh and standard throughout Indonesia is the placing of a chair or table over the suspect's foot, which the interrogator then sits on,'' it said. Indonesia does not admit international human rights organizations for official observation, but Asia Watch hopes to be represented unofficially at the open trials in the cities of Medan, Banda Aceh and Lhokseumawe, Ms. Jones said by telephone from New York. Asia Watch is affiliated with Helsinki Watch and other groups that promote observance of human rights set forth in the 1975 Helsinki East-West agreement. Ms. Jones said she discussed human rights at a meeting with Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas at the United Nations this fall, and later visited Sumatra privately. She quoted Alatas as telling her that Asia Watch could come to his country officially when it ``stops taunting'' Indonesia. She said she replied that ``international pressure is critical to bring about improvements in the human rights situation, and what they call taunting we call constructive criticism.''

DOC.HEAD: Santa Wins $1 Million Three Days After Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Santa is usually considered a bearer of gifts, but this Santa got a big present of her own. Santa Daumann, a 59-year-old grandmother from the New York City borough of Brooklyn, won more than $1 million Friday playing slot machines at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino. Mrs. Daumann, a bookkeeper, said she went to Atlantic City with her husband, Al, determined to ``hit the big one.'' After playing for 45 minutes, she won $1,137,813.32, casino officials said. She said she had no immediate plans for the money.

DOC.HEAD: Comedian Hope, Back from Entertaining Troops, Calls Morale High
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Bob Hope, back from a round of USO Christmas shows in the Persian Gulf region, says American troops are in high spirits despite their desert ordeal. ``We found the morale over there just sensational,'' the 87-year-old Hope told a news conference Friday night at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. ``My opening line in the last week has been, `Are you ready?''' he said. ``And, man, they all stood up with a fist and said, `We're ready.''' Hope confessed that he and his entourage were tired after a 20-hour flight from Bahrain that seemed like ``the longest flight of my career.'' He said the gulf trip would be the last of the Christmas tours to entertain American troops overseas that began during World War II and continued through Korea and Vietnam. Hope was accompanied by his wife, Dolores, actress-singer Ann Jillian, former Cincinnati Reds baseball star Johnny Bench and country singer Aaron Tippin. Hope was asked to compare morale among the troops in the gulf with that of Vietnam. ``They know more what they're doing,'' he said. In deference to Saudi religious customs, Hope toned down the racy jokes and did without the scantily clad beauties who have been included in shows in years past. Reporters were banned from covering the performances. Ms. Jillian and other female performers did entertain troops aboard ship off Bahrain. ``We referred to ourselves as the pantyhose division of Bob Hope's USO tour,'' she said. Portions of shows at camps across Saudi Arabia and aboard ship will be spliced together for a 90-minute special to be telecast by NBC on Jan. 12. Hope said he has been going on Christmas tours so long that in 1983 some servicemen told him that their grandfathers had seen him. But he added: ``If anybody tells you I was in the Civil War, I'm denying it.''

DOC.HEAD: Suriname Coup Condemned By OAS
DOC.TEXT: The Political Council of the Organization of American States has appealed for reinstatement of a democratic government in Suriname and denounced the military coup that overthrew that nation's elected leadership. Twenty-four of the 32 governments in the OAS quickly joined Venezuela's sponsorship of a resolution denouncing the Dec. 24 coup, in which President Ramsewak Shankar was forced from office. Suriname is a former Dutch colony located on the northern coast of South America. The United States and all Latin American representatives, with the exception of Honduras, endorsed the Venezuelan request despite a request from the Surinamese ambassador to delay action. Ambassador Glenn A. Alvares had asked the council for the postponement until ``we have sufficient information of what happened in Suriname to act in conformity with the realities.'' But the Venezuelan representative, Guido Grooscors, refused to accept a delay, calling the coup an intolerable action against the will of the people of Suriname. ``The use of armed force to take decisions in the political field must be eradicated from this continent,'' he said. U.S. Representative Luigi Einaudi said: ``We cannot be silent about the events in Suriname that deprive the Surinamese people of their rights. We cannot allow those illegal acts to threaten the democracy now developing in Latin America. ``The United States condemns the violation of constitutional order in Suriname and calls on the Surinamese military to restore power immediately to the democratically elected authorities of that country.'' Earlier this month President Bush visited South America, emphasizing the movement away from military government and dictatorship. In Paramaribo, the Surinamese capital, President Shankar and his cabinet handed their resignations to Parliament on Friday. Parliament was expected to name a new president and vice president by Saturday. The resolution adopted by the OAS council ``appeals for the reinstatement of the democratic institutional order and the avoidance of any act that could aggravate the situation and impair the full enjoyment of human rights.''

DOC.HEAD: Dominican Tired Of Cold Winters Accused Of Trying To Steal Plane
DOC.TEXT: A native of the Dominican Republic, fed up with cold Canadian winters, has been arrested after trying to steal an airplane and fly himself home, police say. Police said the 24-year-old man climbed over a fence at Montreal's Dorval airport after dark Friday and forced his way into an empty twin-engine plane at Avionair Inc., a charter-flight company. ``He started to get something going inside the cockpit when he was intercepted by one of the workers,'' said Det. Sgt. Kevin McCready of the Montreal police. Police refused to release the name of the suspect but said he has landed-immigrant status and has been in Canada since 1988. He was depressed and wanted to return to his native country, McCready said. ``He said he wanted to go home. He doesn't like our winters,'' McCready said. The man did not have a pilot's license and McCready believed he did not know how to fly the plane, which seats six passengers.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Protests OMB Budget Decisions
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan says millions of sick, elderly or poor Americans will suffer if proposed cuts in his budget are implemented. The reductions would leave Sullivan's agency unable to maintain current services in programs like Medicare and Social Security, the secretary said in a letter to the White House protesting the Office of Management and Budget's proposed cuts. He said the result would be longer processing times for claims. Sullivan's letter said also that the OMB proposal would provide inadequate funds to turn more attention to prenatal care and expansion of programs to combat lead poisoning, breast cancer, tuberculosis and AIDS, as the department wants to do. The letter, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press on Friday, was sent last Friday night to OMB Director Richard Darman. First word of it appeared in Friday's New York Times. A department budget official said that during the past week much progress had been made in negotiations with OMB, but he declined to give specifics. The negotiations are continuing, he said. The letter said that cuts in funds for administration of the Health Care Financing Administration, which handles Medicare and Medicaid, and the Social Security Administration could hurt ``our ability to respond to the needs of 50 million aged and disabled beneficiaries.'' Kevin Moley, HHS assistant secretary for management and budget, said that while the figure of 50 million was correct when the letter was written a week ago, it is ``far fewer today than last week, and we expect to resolve those issues by the time we announce our budget.'' Moley declined to say how much money was in dispute, and the letter did not spell out the total. Sullivan's letter of appeal is part of the annual budget-making process. After a department drafts a budget request, OMB reviews it, makes changes and sends the resulting proposal, called a ``pass back,'' to the department. The department then negotiates with OMB and, if still not satisfied, may appeal to the president himself. It is rare that any agency head is satisfied with OMB's ``pass back.'' President Bush will give his budget proposal, covering the 1992 fiscal year beginning on Oct. 1, 1991, to Congress in early February. OMB's ``pass back'' to HHS would cut Medicare by $2.7 billion in addition to the nearly $6 billion agreed to in the deficit-reduction package approved by the administration and Congress in October. The extra cuts would come from payments to physicians and hospitals. The proposed cuts in administrative expenses of Social Security would increase the backlog of telephone calls and mean more busy signals, Sullivan's letter said. Sullivan said the department needs an additional $82 million beyond what OMB would provide for efforts to get high-risk women into prenatal care. These efforts would help reduce the United States' high infant mortality rate and reduce costs for care of premature infants, he said. Sullivan also wants $143 million beyond OMB's proposal for programs that increase access to health care for minorities and the disadvantaged. The secretary also told Darman he wants to further decrease the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program to $468 million, which has been running at about $1 billion a year in recent years, and ``target it to the Northeast states where low-income residents are most likely to use fuel oil to heat their homes.''

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Cuban Medical Worker Defects
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban medical worker fled to a Colombian island the day he was due to return to his homeland, a newspaper reports. It was the fourth defection in six weeks by a member of Cuba's volunteer medical brigades in Nicaragua. Barricada, official newspaper of the leftist Sandinista Front, reported Friday that Fausto Mambes Ramirez left the Atlantic Coast port town of Bluefields earlier this month for Corn Island, a nearby Nicaraguan island. The 43-year-old anesthesiologist, traveling aboard a private speedboat, then went to the Colombian island of San Andres, the paper said, citing unspecified official information. A call to the Cuban Embassy in Managua, seeking independent confirmation, was not immediately returned. Barricada said Ramirez left on Dec. 22, the day he was to return to Cuba after completing his second stint as a volunteer medical worker in Bluefields, 200 miles southeast of Managua. Despite this year's change from a leftist to a pro-U.S. government in Nicaragua, Cuba's Communist government has continued to send medical brigades totaling about 300 people, half of them doctors. In late November, two Cuban doctors and a male nurse defected and were allowed to travel to neighboring Costa Rica. The incident proved an embarrassment for the Nicaraguan government, which doesn't want to jeopardize the aid provided by the Cuban medical brigades.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Resigns to Pave Way for New Government Line-up
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's 10-month-old Cabinet resigned today after intense party pressure to allow other senior politicians to hold prestigious government posts, a top official said. Kaifu's new Cabinet was to be announced this evening. Many key ministers are expected to retain their posts and no major policy changes were expected. The make-up of the new Cabinet has been the subject of intense debate within the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Kaifu is strongly opposed to demands by some senior party leaders to bring back politicians who were tainted by an influence-peddling scandal last year. Whether Kaifu can keep his Cabinet free of politicians linked to the scandal, in which the Recruit job-placement conglomerate offered lucrative unlisted stock to influential politicians, is being viewed by analysts as a test of his political clout. There was no immediate official announcement of the Cabinet reshuffle, but politicians leaving an afternoon meeting with Kaifu indicated the resignations had been tendered. A top government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed that all 21 Cabinet members had handed letters of resignation to Kaifu upon his request. ``Nothing is going to change except faces in the Cabinet profile book,'' said Masaya Ito, a prominent political analyst who served as secretary to the late Prime Minister Hayato Ikeda. Japan's Cabinet is typically reshuffled annually to give desirable assignments to senior lawmakers of the Liberal Democratic Party. The party is comprised of five major factions, each headed by a powerful politician who aspires to become prime minister and to win Cabinet posts for his allies. Because he belongs to the smallest faction, Kaifu is regarded as having a weak power base and needs to compromise with other faction leaders. Kaifu originally had said he would not announce a change before the new year in an effort to display some independence, but apparently changed his mind after meeting Friday afternoon with Ichiro Ozawa, the party's powerful secretary general.

DOC.HEAD: Public Focused More Attention Gulf Crisis In 1990
DOC.TEXT: Americans paid more attention to the Persian Gulf crisis than to any other news story in 1990 - a year in which domestic news reports were dominated by international events, a survey shows. Two-thirds of the public closely followed stories about the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the deployment of U.S. forces in the region over the last five months, according to the survey by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press. But Americans showed little interest in the historic fall of communism in almost all of Eastern Europe and the economic and political turmoil in the Soviet Union. The survey said that at no point did more than 30 percent of Americans closely follow these events. The Mideast events also figured in the most closely followed domestic news story of the year. Sixty-two percent of those surveyed said they regularly read stories about soaring gasoline prices in August and September. By comparison, reports in November about the declining economy attracted only 39 percent of the readers on a regular basis. Stories leaing up to and including the November general election caught the regular attention of only 38 percent, as did stories last January about the war against drugs. Only one other news event, also involving U.S. soldiers fighting abroad, caught the close attention of more than a majority Americans: Sixty percent of Americans regularly read stories about the U.S. invasion of Panama. Although U.S. troops invaded Panama in December, 1989, their presence in the country and numerous news stories continued into 1990. According to the survey, the Times Mirror News Interest Index, public interest in some issues shifted significantly during the year. Last spring, only 18 percent of the public paid close attention to stories about the first signs of economic problems. By September that percentage had increased to 29 percent and in November it was 39 percent. There was only scant attention to the nation's budget deficit last spring when Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., proposed a deficit reduction plan. During the summer as Congress debated a budget package 18 percent of the readers were following the issue closely with public attention increasing to 34 percent by the fall amid threats to shut down the federal government. Interest in news concerning President Bush also fluctuated widely during the year. When Bush attended the drug summit in Columbia last February, only 22 percent of the public paid close attention to news stories about the visit. Criticism of the president on his changing position on taxes and his Persian Gulf policy caught the close attention of slightly less than a third of the public. By contrast, three out of four people read last March about Bush's distaste for broccoli. Sensational crimes and trials brought substantial public interest during 1990. News about the serial killings in Gainesville, Fla., attracted more public attention - 36 percent - than any other crime story during the year. Twenty-eight percent of the readers followed the drug arrest of Mayor Marion Barry of Washington D.C., but interest waned. Only 16 percent paid close attention to stories about Barry's conviction on some of the charges. Some stories attracted less public interest than expected. Despite the extensive coverage of the nomination of David Souter to the U.S. Supreme Court, only about 15 percent followed the event closely. And more than half of the people surveyed said they strongly felt too much was written about the marital breakup of Donald and Ivana Trump. Twelve percent of the public said they closely followed the affair. Here are a few other major news events and their interest quotient: -The Supreme Court decision affirming the right to burn the flag, 24 percent. -The Super Bowl, 22 percent. -The controversy surrounding Roseanne Barr's singing of the national anthem, 21 percent. -Continuing news last June about the savings and loan scandal, 18 percent. -The election in Nicaragua, 19 percent. -The death of 87 people in a first at a New York City social club, 28 percent. -Political changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, 26 to 28 percent. Among the news stories in the survey that attracted the least interest were: the United Nation's children's summit, 6 percent; civil war in Cambodia, 4 percent, and actor Tom Cruise's separation from his wife, 2 percent. The 1990 survey reflects monthly telephone polls of about 1,200 adults nationwide. Each monthly survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Opponents Of Coup Refuse To Vote For Army's Presidential Nominee
DOC.TEXT: Some parliament members protesting a military coup say they will cast blank ballots rather than take part in voting for an army-backed president. The National Assembly was scheduled to vote today on the military's proposal for Johan Kraag to assume the presidency of the South American nation and lead an interim government that would organize elections within 100 days. The army needs at least 34 votes in the 51-member National Assembly to confirm the selection of Kraag and his proposed vice president, Jules Wijdenbosch. But at least one assembly member said he and some colleagues would cast blank ballots to protest the Christmas Eve ouster of President Ramsewak Shankar. Shankar had been locked in a dispute with Desi Bouterse, who headed a military dictatorship that ruled the former Dutch colony from 1980-88. Bouterse is widely believed to have planned the coup. Kraag belongs to the National Party of Suriname, the party of ousted Vice President Henck Arron. Wijdenbosch is chairman of the National Democratic Party, which was organized by Bouterse. Shankar and his Cabinet formally submitted their resignations to the parliament Friday. The military claims Suriname's constitution permits military intervention as long as the National Assembly is left intact. Shankar's former coalition has 40 seats in the assembly, and the National Democratic Party has three seats. Cmdr. Ivan Graanoogst, acting army chief, said the new president will set the election date and the interim government will decide whether to allow international observers to monitor the elections. Bouterse met Friday with Lugo Turon, a special emissary from Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez, and told him ``the army will keep its word and there will be elections,'' an army statement said. The ethnically diverse nation of 400,000 people has suffered a progressive economic crisis since 1980. The Dutch government cut off aid payments after Bouterse killed 15 of his political opponents in 1982. The economy has also been hurt by a guerrilla war and plunging world prices for bauxite, the main export. In Washington, the Organization of American States denounced the military takeover. The United States and all Latin American representatives except Honduras also criticized it. Their resolution Friday ``appeals for the reinstatement of the democratic institutional order'' in Suriname. Luigi Einaudi, the U.S. delegate to the OAS, said: ``We cannot be silent about the events in Suriname that deprive the Surinamese people of their rights. We can not allow those illegal acts to threaten the democracy now developing in Latin America.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Goverment Ties Highway Funding to Stricter Drug Laws
DOC.TEXT: California stopped telling casual marijuana users ``smoke a joint, go to jail'' 15 years ago. But the federal government's new version - ``smoke a joint, lose your driver's license'' - promises to rekindle debate over the state's pot law. A little-noted amendment to a new federal highway funding law seeks to use federal funding as a weapon against liberal state drug laws. It would particularly affect California and New York because of those states' relatively liberal marijuana laws and large amounts of federal funding. The federal law calls for every state to pass a law in 1991-92 requiring a six-month driver license suspension for anyone convicted of violating any drug law, including possession of marijuana for personal use. States that refuse could lose 5 percent of their federal highway aid in the 12 months starting Oct. 1, 1993. That would be $60 million at current levels of aid to California, said the amendment's sponsor, Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y. The amendment passed in July. New York's penalty would be an estimated $16 million, said state Transporation Department spokesman David Ernst. The penalty would become 10 percent two years later. The penalty appears modest in light of California's $55 billion budget. But with 1991's state deficit projected as high as $10 billion, any potential loss of revenue is a sensitive issue. Gov.-elect Pete Wilson has not taken a position on driver license suspensions, but press secretary Bill Livingstone said Wilson agrees with outgoing federal drug overseer William Bennett that California's drug laws are too lenient. Wilson cannot require the Democratic-controlled Legislature to pass a license suspension law, but his position could determine the fiscal impact on the state. Solomon's amendment lets a state avoid a monetary penalty only if both the Legislature and the governor oppose the requirement of license suspensions. California liberalized its marijuana law in 1975. Possession of an ounce or less, which previously could be prosecuted as a felony with a state prison sentence, is now subject to a $100 fine, with no jail time or permanent criminal record. The state requires a four-month license suspension for drunken drivers but doesn't suspend licenses for drinking, drug use or drug possession unrelated to driving. Any action by the New York state Legislature on the requirement probably wouldn't come for several years, after the federal government issues details of how the highway program would be run. ``We're aware of the law. We're waiting for the regulations to see how to best proceed,'' said Christopher Cernik, counsel to Assemblyman Michael Bragman, chairman of the Assembly Transportation Committee. A spokesman for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, Gordon Brownell, called the mandatory license suspension ``tantamount to a recriminalization'' and a ``federally imposed interference with California public policy.'' In California, the chairmen of the legislative committees that would handle the license suspension bill both criticized the federal law but declined to predict the state's response. Sen. Bill Lockyer, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said he generally favored minimal sentences for possessing small amounts of marijuana, but was noncommittal on the license suspension proposal. Assemblyman John Burton, chairman of the Assembly Public Safety Committee, said he opposed the license suspension as unwarranted federal interference, as well as on its merits. ``Driving under the influence of a drug is one thing, possessing it is another,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Victories Over Rwandan Forces
DOC.TEXT: Rebels in Rwanda say they have killed more than 70 government soldiers in recent clashes in the northern part of the Central African country. In a statement released in the Ugandan capital Friday, the Rwandan Patriotic Front said its guerrillas inflicted the losses in six skirmishes against government forces in the week before Christmas. The statement put rebel losses at 11 dead and 37 injured. Referring to a recent government claim that it had killed 400 rebels, the statement said most of those slain by Rwandan soldiers had been civilians. Independent casualty figures were unavailable. ``The truth of the matter is that after being hit by our troops, the regime's forces turn on innocent civilians,'' the statement said. The rebels, mostly members of Rwanda's Tutsi ethnic minority, entered their homeland nearly three months ago from neighboring Uganda, where they had been living in exile.

DOC.HEAD: Sleuths Sniffing for Fake Perfumes also Find VapoRub
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ELIMINATES redundant ``owns'' in 3rd graf `The Nov. 22...'
DOC.TEXT: Investigators looking for the counterfeiters of several famous brands of perfumes found a more common but no less distinctive trademark - bogus jars of Vicks Vaporub. Sleuths hired to track down suppliers of phony Yves Saint Laurent and Giorgio scents discovered 10,000 fake jars of the cold remedy in a raid on an illicit perfume laboratory. The Nov. 22 raid was confirmed this week by Brandt Handley, director of marketing for Procter and Gamble, the Cincinnati-based company that owns Richardson-Vicks Inc. The bogus Vaporub jars with Arabic words in addition to English on the label were intended for sale in the Middle East, Handley said. Valid Vaporub, made in neighboring Malaysia, has only English and Chinese lettering for the regional market. The salve is sold in more than 100 countries and made in more than a dozen legitimate plants around the world, from its birthplace in North Carolina to factories in Mexico, India and Australia. Handley said his company's trademark had been ripped off sporadically over the past 15 years. The latest batch smelled more like Chinese medicated oil than the distinctive mix of menthol, camphor and eucalyptus oil. Responding to pressure from the United States, Singapore tightened its copyright laws in 1987. This was an attempt to end its reputation as one of the hubs of counterfeit goods ranging from computer software to clothing, books, watches, perfumes and music and video recordings. U.S. officials complained that the copying, often called piracy, cost legitimate producers hundreds of millions of dollars a year in lost revenue. Five years ago pirated cassettes accounted for 90 percent of all tape sales in Singapore. Tens of millions of illicit pre-recorded cassettes were exported each year. The 1984 Band Aid charity recording of ``Do They Know It's Christmas,'' produced to aid famine victims in Ethiopia, was pirated in Singapore two weeks after it was released in Britain. Singapore's role as the major world center for sham scents peaked in 1987-88 when 800,000 bottles were exported annually, said Jean-Louis Faure, security director of Yves Saint Laurent. Perfume pirates took advantage of the country's excellent shipping facilities and duty-free status to import components cheaply. The bottles generally came from Taiwan and essences could be ordered from specialist companies in France and Switzerland. They prospered because the equipment needed could be cheaply installed in an apartment and the penalties were relatively light. After pursuing the pirates for years with limited success, manufacturers hope that a recent series of raids mark a turning point. Private investigators mounted 17 raids in the last 14 months. Two of the last three major illicit perfumeries known to be operating were hit in November, Faure said. They found the Vaporub in one of those raids, apparently a synthetic sideline.

DOC.HEAD: Texas House Speaker Indicted On Misdemeanor Ethics Violations
DOC.TEXT: The Texas House speaker was indicted on charges he accepted $5,000 from a law firm and didn't disclose it, joining legislative leaders in the two other most populous states under an ethical cloud. House speakers in New York and California also are under scrutiny as they prepare for new legislative sessions. The investigation in Texas also involves other legislators. A Travis County grand jury returned indictments on two misdemeanor charges Friday against Gib Lewis, alleging he solicited and received a gift from the San Antonio-based law firm of Heard Goggan Blair & Williams, then failed to report it. Despite the charges, Lewis' lawyer said the lawmaker would seek an unprecedented fifth term as House speaker. ``I don't see any legal reason or otherwise why he shouldn't be elected to the speakership,'' attorney Bill Willms said. The 150-member House will elect a speaker Jan. 8, the first day of the regular legislative session. The first charge alleges the law firm paid part of a tax bill Lewis owed. The second claims he failed to disclose the payment as a gift on his public financial disclosure statement. The maximum penalty upon conviction of both charges is 1{ years in jail and a $3,000 fine. ``Although these crimes are misdemeanors, they are among the most serious crimes a public official can be charged with,'' prosecutor Ronnie Earle said Friday. Lewis, a Fort Worth Democrat, has denied any wrongdoing, and his lawyers said he would plead innocent. Lawyer Allen Hill and other defense attorneyes said the charges were politically motivated. Lewis, 54, was traveling and unavailable for comment on the indictment, said his spokesman, Monte Williams. The grand jury, which will remain in session for another three months, also is investigating an April 1987 trip to Mexico that Lewis took with four partners in the law firm, an Austin lobbyist and six women, one of whom reportedly was a topless dancer named Chrissee. ``There are a number of allegations remaining under investigation concerning Mr. Lewis, various members of the Legislature and lobbyists,'' Earle said. Heard Goggan, one of the few law firms in Texas with contracts to collect delinquent taxes for local governments, paid about half of a $10,433 delinquent tax bill owed by a company partly owned by Lewis, the indictment claims. Lewis has said the payment represented a ``business settlement.'' As speaker for the last eight years, Lewis has controlled the House, assigning bills to committees, naming their chairmen and directing floor debate. Earle said the indictments were issued Friday to meet the statute of limitations on misdemeanor charges and because of the upcoming election for House speaker. In the past eight years, the law firm has flourished under a state law that allows a private firm hired by local governments to add a 15 percent fee onto overdue tax bills. Numerous legislative attempts aimed at changing the law have died in House committees. In New York, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller pleaded innocent Dec. 20 to federal mail fraud harges involving allegations of a real estate scam. Miller, a Democrat from New York City, and top aide and former law partner Jay Adolf were indicted on 19 counts of mail fraud, conspiracy and falsifying documents. The charges stem from Miller's private law practice and Miller claims they amount to a political witch hunt. California Assembly Speaker Willie Brown reportedly is being investigated about allegations that he was involved in legislation aimed at helping a regional garbage company get around local restrictions on landfills. Brown has not been charged with any crime and denies any impropriety.

DOC.HEAD: Father: `Nancy's Free at Last'
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan is ``free at last,'' her father said at a tearful funeral amid proud reflections on the young woman's role in the national right-to-die debate. Ms. Cruzan's nearly eight-year journey to death resulted in a landmark U.S. Supreme Court decision and a 500-fold jump in inquiries about living wills, Joe Cruzan told mourners Friday. Living wills allow adults to specify in advance their wishes about life-sustaining treatment. ``I believe that these facts speak to the legacy that Nancy left us,'' he told more than 200 mourners. ``She did not die in vain.'' Ms. Cruzan, 33, severely brain damaged in a 1983 car accident, died Wednesday at Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon, 12 days after her feeding tube was removed. She was buried in Carterville Cemetery just north of Joplin. Mourners crowded under a broad green tent to view her blue metal casket, which was etched with flying sea gulls and decorated with about two dozen bright floral arrangements. The flowers included a single red rose from Ms. Cruzan's grandparents, a red, white and blue arrangement from her 1975 Webb City High School graduating class and violets from the cheese plant where she worked. Before the burial, 13 photographs of Ms. Cruzan were displayed above the casket, including one of her as an infant bundled for winter play, as a little girl wrestling with a too-tall bicycle and as a smiling young woman. ``We all feel good that Nancy is free at last,'' Joe Cruzan told reporters. ``It was time.'' After most mourners left, he returned for a moment alone and placed a pink flower on the grave. Ms. Cruzan's parents waged a long legal battle for permission to remove the feeding tube, contending their daughter would rather die than continue in a persistent vegetative state. But their request was stymied because she left no written instructions about being kept alive. In its first right-to-die decision, the Supreme Court ruled in June that Missouri could require ``clear and convincing evidence'' to verify Ms. Cruzan's intentions. A federal judge ruled that the family did provide such evidence and the feeding tube was removed. Ms. Cruzan died 12 days later. Demonstrators kept a death watch outside the hospital and made unsuccessful pleas to Missouri and federal courts to reconnect the feeding tube. There were no protests at the funeral or burial.

DOC.HEAD: Weapons And Cash Found In Ershad's Home
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reported today that investigators have seized 15 weapons, cash and luxury goods worth over $100,000 from the home of deposed President Hussain Muhammad Ershad. Police have told Ershad he is suspected of corruption and abusing his office, but formal charges have not been filed. Ittefaq, a Bengali-language daily, quoted an unidentified source close to the investigating team as saying seven shotguns, six pistols and two revolvers were found in Ershad's official residence located in a complex of military barracks and officers' homes. All the weapons except for three handguns were unlicensed, the paper said, quoting the source. The team comprising a magistrate, police and army officials examined Ershad's property after the former army general was escorted from his house Dec. 12 and placed under house arrest in an exclusive suburb. Ershad resigned Dec. 6, yielding to 7-week-long mass protests against his government. Ittefaq said the list of seized property is still incomplete. But it said $60,000 in cash was found along with 30 trunks of gold ornaments, crystal and luxury items which may push the value beyond $100,000. ``The investigating team has found certain illegal items which should not have been at an official residence of a president,'' the paper said, without saying what they were. The list will be handed over to a government-appointed commission investigating the suspicions against Ershad, who ruled Bangladesh for more than eight years. The caretaker government which replaced Ershad also has arrested four former officials, including ex-Vice President Moudud Ahmed, and is seeking 14 more officials of the ousted regime.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Airlifts Ailing Swedish Woman From Iraqi ``Peace Ship''
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A 56-year-old Swedish woman, one of several Western peace activists aboard an Iraqi ship intercepted in the Arabian Sea, has been airlifted to a hospital by a U.S. Navy helicopter, a U.S. spokesman reported today. The Iraqi captain of the 11,000-ton Ibn Khaldoon, forced to anchor off the coast of Oman on Wednesday, radioed for help around midnight Thursday, the spokesman said. The woman was reported to be suffering ``chest pains and gastrointestinal distress'' and a medical officer from the amphibious transport dock USS Trenton was sent aboard to examine her, the spokesman said. Later, a helicopter from the assault carrier Iwo Jima flew the unidentified woman to the warship for further checks. She was transferred to a shore hospital Friday, the spokesman said, without disclosing which medical center. Her current condition was not immediately known. The Ibn Khaldoon was stopped Wednesday by Western warships in the nothern Arabian Sea outside the Strait of Hormuz, gateway to the Persian Gulf. They were enforcing the United Nations economic embargo on Iraq for invading Kuwait Aug. 2. Boarding parties found the ship, which was heading for Iraq's southern port of Umm Qasr, was carrying 800 tons of sugar as well as cooking oil and rice, all banned under the embargo. The Ibn Khaldoon was also carrying scores of peace activists from Arab, Asian and Western countries who were heading for Iraq in a demonstration of support for President Saddam Hussein. Iraq's media said the activists included American, Japanese, Chinese and European peace campaigners. The women tried to resist the boarding teams. U.S. officials said there were no injuries in the scuffles. But the Iraqi media claimed the Western sailors beat the passengers with clubs and rifle butts, causing some injuries. The U.S. Navy said there were 161 women, 66 men and 14 children on the ship, including the 42-man crew, when it was boarded. They will be allowed to continue the voyage to Iraq once the cargo has been unloaded, officials said. The U.S. spokesman said the so-called ``peace ship'' was anchored off the Omani island of Masirah while the captain awaited the outcome of diplomatic contacts deciding at what port he could discharge his cargo. The Trenton and other warships of the U.S.-led multinational armada in the region maintained a watch over the Ibn Khaldoon.

DOC.HEAD: Judges Clear Way for Landmark MCA Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Japan's largest consumer electronics company won two legal victories to clear the way for the expected completion today of its landmark $6.6 billion purchase of entertainment conglomerate MCA Inc. Matsushita Electrical Industrial Co.'s takeover of MCA would be the largest Japanese purchase of a U.S. company. It would resemble the buyout by Japan's Sony Corp. of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for $5 billion a year ago. The merger would give Matsushita, familiar to American consumers through brand names such as Panasonic, Technics and Quasar, the entertainment ``software'' it needs to complement its electronics ``hardware.'' MCA, owner of Universal Studios, has grown into a colossus of films (``E.T. the Extra-Terrestial,'' ``Jaws,'' ``Back to the Future''), as well as records (Reba McEntire, Elton John, Guns N' Roses) and television (``Murder, She Wrote,'' ``Major Dad''). It also owns theme parks in Florida and California. Matsushita officials worked through the night to complete the $66-a-share tender offer for MCA today, Matsushita spokeswoman Joele Frank said from New York. ``The tender offer is currently scheduled to come down, but until it's done I can't say anything,'' Frank said by telephone early today. She said the company would not release details until Sunday. On Friday, a federal judge in Los Angeles refused a bid by several MCA shareholders to block the sale. They alleged that MCA chairman Lew Wasserman violated Securities and Exchange Commission rules by receiving tax-free stock transfers as part of Matsushita's tender offer for MCA's stock. While not dismissing the lawsuit, U.S. District Judge Manuel Real said there was insufficient evidence presented to block the transaction. In a separate case, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia denied a last-minute motion in a lawsuit by Go-Video Inc. to stop the sale. The Arizona manufacturer of dual-deck VCRs alleged the deal would violate antitrust rules. Matsushita, one of the world's largest corporations with $38 billion in sales recorded last fiscal year, would become the majority shareholder of MCA, but would not assume ownership of the company until early next year. Ernest Kaufmann, an attorney for the objecting MCA shareholders, said his clients would continue pursuing the class-action lawsuit seeking unspecified cash damages. As part of the MCA buyout, Wasserman alone is to receive a new preferred Matsushita stock designed to save him $100 million in capital gains taxes and additional estate taxes. ``Our shareholders, on the other hand, are facing enormous tax problems,'' Kaufmann said. Matsushita is issuing preferred stock worth $330 million to Wasserman in return for Wasserman's 4.95 million shares of MCA stock. The stock, in a new Matsushita subsidiary, pays an annual dividend of 8.75 percent. In an earlier interview, Wasserman defended the unusual stock plan. Asked if he would enjoy an unfair tax advantage over other MCA shareholders, Wasserman said, ``Well, is that against the law?''

DOC.HEAD: Another Brawl Breaks Out In Legislature After Vote On Prisoner Clemency
LaserPhoto TPE2
DOC.TEXT: The parliament speaker ducked out under a barrage of fruit, wastepaper baskets and tea cups after passage of a clemency bill ignited the latest scuffle among lawmakers. Police with shields protected Speaker Liang Su-jung, who fled the hall as opposition Democratic Progressive Party politicians tangled with Nationalist Party colleagues, many in their 80s or older, witnessess said. No one was seriously hurt in the 10-minute skirmish late Friday, but Democratic Progressive lawmaker Hsieh Chang-tien suffered a bloody nose and dozens of other legislators' suits were stained with tea, officials reported. They were elected in China before 1949, when the Nationalists lost a civil war to Communists and retreated to Taiwan. Fights have been common among the 243 members of the lawmaking body, or Yuan, since opposition parties were legalized last year. The Nationalist Party holds 215 seats and the Democratic Progressive Party has 13. The latest brawl began when Democratic Progressive lawmakers organized a filibuster of a clemency bill, seeking to force an amendment to reduce the jail sentences of dozens of its supporters convicted of beating policemen in demonstrations. Nationalists opposed the change. Pandemonium erupted when Liang announced that 77 of the 84 legislators present voted to override the filibuster and passed the bill. The seven Democratic Progressive legislators refrained from voting, and they immediately began tossing wastepaper baskets and punching those who tried to calm them. During the voting, Democratic Progressive legislators lobbed fruit and cups of tea at Nationalist members to distract them. Fruit is regularly supplied to legislators attending lengthy sessions. Democratic Progressive legislator Tai Chen-yao tossed Liang's chair down from the podium to protest his departure.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys General Accuse Kellogg Of Deceptive Cereal Claims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for the ST. PAUL, Minn.-dated story on PM-News Advisory
DOC.TEXT: Tony the Tiger says Frosted Flakes are grrrreat, but attorneys general from five states claim he isn't telling the full story. The officials allege Kellogg Co. used deceptive and misleading health claims about Frosted Flakes and two other cereals. A company spokesman denied the accusations. In documents filed Friday in federal court in Des Moines, Iowa, the attorneys general responded to Kellogg's claims made in a lawsuit filed in August against the Iowa attorney general and secretary of agriculture. The lawsuit and counterclaims stem from an investigation into Kellogg's advertising that began two years ago. The officials from Minnesota, California, Florida, Texas and Wisconsin also made several counterclaims, among them that Kellogg's lacks ``reasonable substantiation'' for claiming Frosted Flakes is a healthy snack food superior to some fruits. Television commercials for the cereal feature the cartoon character Tony the Tiger. Regarding Special K, the officials said Kellogg's misrepresented the cereal's benefit by saying those who eat it can ``keep the muscle, lose the fat.'' They said such representation failed to disclose that ``for the vast majority of consumers and even for those on a diet, eating one serving of Special K would have virtually no effect on preventing the loss of muscle as the majority of dieters are in no danger of losing muscle, and for those who are, a serving of Special K would be insignificant...'' Kellogg's claim that a cereal formerly named 40+ Bran Flakes had a particular benefit because it contained the ``maximum amount of fiber plus iron'' for people over 40 failed to say the cereal was not formulated particularly for people over 40, the officials said. In addition, there was no proof that people over 40 needed the ingredients contained in the cereal more than younger people, they said. Kellogg no longer markets its bran flake cereal under the 40+ name. Joseph Stewart, Kellogg's senior vice president for corporate affairs, said the company, based in Battle Creek, Mich., stands behind its advertising. ``The federal authority over advertising exists and these individuals are attempting now to regulate advertisements state-by-state,'' he said. Kellogg has promoted Special K as a high protein cereal for more than 35 years, he said, and claims the cereal can help retain muscle while losing fat when eaten as part of a regimen that includes exercise. Frosted Flakes has 11 grams of sugar while an apple, for example, has 14 grams of sugar, Stewart said. He said Kellogg officials at first sought to negotiate with Iowa officials, but now contend the accusations amount to harassment.

DOC.HEAD: Man Survives Train Mishap By Lying Down in Middle of Tracks
DOC.TEXT: A man headed for a liquor store was unharmed but had a soot-blackened face after a commuter train ran over him. ``I was on my way to the liquor store to buy a bottle of vodka. I looked up and all I saw was a headlight headed my way,'' Anselmo Castillo Campos, 35, said from jail where he was taken for investigation of public drunkenness. ``All I could do was lay down in the middle of the tracks.'' Santa Clara Police officer Floyd Worley, who arrested the 5-foot-2, 135-pound Campos after the Thursday afternoon accident, said it was a miracle Campos survived the brush with the three-car CalTrain commuter express, which was going about 20 mph. ``I'd like to get his five luckiest numbers for the lottery,'' Worley said. The train, on its way to San Francisco, was delayed 25 minutes while paramedics and police examined Campos, who smiled and waved to bystanders.

DOC.HEAD: Somalia Appeals For Public Support Against Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Faced with a growing wave of violence and unrest, Somalia has appealed for public support for a crackdown on various armed gangs and rebels bent on overthrowing the government of President Mohamed Siad Barre. The appeal for public support by Information Minister Umar Muhammad Abd Al-Rahman came late Friday after a government announcement of new clashes between security forces and armed gangs Thursday. The government said two gunmen were killed and more than 20 arrested in the shootout in a shantytown on the northern outskirts of Somalia's capital, Mogadishu. But unofficial reports reaching Nairobi, the capital of neighboring Kenya, spoke of many more deaths and hundreds of arrests by security forces in the Somali capital. In a broadcast monitored in Nairobi, Somali National Radio said Al-Rahman appealed to the people of the country to collaborate with the security forces. ``The minister appealed to the Somali masses to show their allegiance by collaborating with the forces engaged in maintaining the country's security and stability,'' the radio said. It was not clear whether security forces were battling lawless elements or rebels in Mogadishu. The government has long used the term ``bandits'' to describe armed rebels. Siad Barre's government has lost ground in recent months to separate rebel groups in the north, center and south of the elbow-shaped nation. His grip on the capital also appears to be slipping. The United Somali Congress, the insurgency fighting in the center of the country, is reported by Western diplomats and others to be within 30 miles of the capital. The Somali National Movement, which began the uprising against Barre's rule two years ago, occupies much of the northern part of the nation. A smaller rebel group, the Somali Patriotic Movement, has tied up government troops with scattered raids in the south. The United States and most other Western nations withdrew all but essential embassy personnel from Mogadishu two weeks ago and urged their nationals to leave the Horn of Africa country.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sentenced to Year in Prison for Inciting Violence
DOC.TEXT: A Revolutionary Communist Party member was sentenced to a year in prison for inciting violence after burning an American flag to protest U.S. military action in the Persian Gulf. Cheryl Lessin, 46, of Cleveland, wore a ``Mao (Tse Tung) more than ever'' T-shirt at her sentencing Friday before Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Judge Patricia Cleary. She plans to appeal. ``I'm being sentenced for daring to be among the first to call out and resist their war movement and for being bold enough to burn their symbol, their flag, despised by oppressed people here and all across the planet,'' Ms. Lessin told the judge. Several of Ms. Lessin's supporters chanted, ``Stop the U.S. war machine no matter what it takes,'' as they left the court building. Others wore tape over their mouths, suggesting the defendant's right to free speech had been violated. Her lawyers said they would request bond while her case was appealed. A jury in October convicted Ms. Lessin of inciting violence after she burned the flag during an Aug. 10 protest. The rally in the downtown Public Square escalated into scuffling and yelling and two police officers testified that Ms. Lessin ran through the crowd throwing punches and shouting obscenities. Ms. Lessin and other witnesses disputed that account. Her lawyers said the judge should have told the jury that flag-burning is a protected form of free speech. The lawyers also said prosecutors incorrectly used a state law against inciting violence.

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Snow Fall Across Much of Midwest, East; Southeast Basks in Warmth
DOC.TEXT: The weekend arrived cold, wet and miserable for most of the United States today, with snow falling in Iowa, Colorado, Minnesota, South Dakota and Idaho, and rain hitting much of the rest of the Midwest and East. Forecasters said the wind chill factor could drop to 80 below in parts of South Dakota today, with conditions nearly as bad in North Dakota, Nebraska, Montana, Utah and Wyoming. Heavy winds were forecast for the Sierra Nevada and California's Mojave Desert, with more frost expected to threaten citrus crops in California and Arizona tonight. Although rain fell on most of the Mid-Atlantic states, high temperatures were expected to rise to the 40s and 50s, as much as 20 degrees over Friday, as a warm air system collided with a cold front. The South, the only region to escape the storm system, had temperatures in the 70s and 80s. Elsewhere, highs ranged from zero or lower along the Canadian border states to the teens and 20s across most of the Midwest, the teens and 20s in the Northwest and the 40s in California. High temperature for the nation Friday was 88 degrees at Naples, Fla.
