DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Company Can't Lobby By Phone for Bankruptcy Plan
DOC.TEXT: A judge has barred the Southland Corp. from contacting bondholders by phone to lobby them to support a bankruptcy reorganization plan that would give control of the convenience store chain to Japanese investors. ``This court isn't in the direct sales or siding business where we call people on the phone,'' U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Harold Abramson said Friday. Southland, parent of the 7-11 convenience stores, filed for Chapter 11 protection in October and reported more than half of its bondholders approved the financial reorganization plan. But Abramson called for another vote after dissident bondholders complained. He also ruled that when ballots for the second vote are mailed the dissidents may include a letter arguing against the proposed reorganization. Under terms of the proposal, Ito-Yokado Co. and Seven-Eleven Japan would invest $430 million in Southland in exchange for 70 percent ownership. The Japanese investors' offer has a March 15 deadline. The dissident bondholders, primarily wealthy individuals, hope to get a sweetened offer from Southland, said their attorney, Peter Wolfson. Southland is confident it will win approval of the plan again, said company spokeswoman Cecelia Norwood.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Riders Arrive for Wounded Knee Observance
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of American Indians gathered in frigid weather to commemorate today's centennial of one of the saddest days in their history - the Wounded Knee massacre. The Indians, traveling by foot and horseback, arrived Friday at the site where hundreds of Sioux, including Chief Big Foot, were slain by U.S. cavalry soldiers on Dec. 29, 1890, in the last major engagement between American Indians and U.S. troops. Tribal leaders, Gov. George Mickelson and Hawaii Sen. Daniel Inouye, who chairs the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, were among those scheduled to participate in commemorative ceremonies. The band of riders left two weeks ago on a 220-mile journey retracing the path taken by Big Foot and his fellow Sioux, as they headed toward the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in southwest South Dakota. ``One hundred years ago, this was the last day Big Foot was free,'' said Alex White Plume, who helped coordinate the ride. ``They didn't know they were going to bloodshed, but today we know what happened.'' Also riding with the group was former American Indian Movement leader Russell Means, who helped lead an armed takeover of Wounded Knee in 1973 to protest treatment of Indians. He said his return to the area he and other protesters held for 71 days filled him with pride. ``Wounded Knee proved to Indian people that it's all right to stand up and be an Indian, and that it's even worth fighting for,'' he said. Two people were killed and several wounded in the takeover, which divided the Sioux nation. Indictments against Means and 115 others eventually were dismissed. After Sioux leader Sitting Bull was killed, Big Foot led a band of Sioux in December 1890 from central South Dakota toward the Pine Ridge reservation. Accounts vary as to who fired first at Wounded Knee, but scores of Sioux men, women and children were killed. Federal officials put the figure at about 150, while Sioux officials say as many as 400 died.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Rumble About Cuba Policy Shift; Havana Braces
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is deliberating its political ties to Cuba and preparing to drastically cut aid next month, while its longtime ally in the Caribbean is bracing for the worst. Cuban President Fidel Castro on Friday spoke of impending dismissals of Communist Party officials during a parliamentary session on ways to restructure the island nation's political and economic system, the Havana-based official news agency Prensa Latina reported. ``Castro expressed that the Central Committee had reached excessive levels of personnel,'' said an agency dispatch monitored in Mexico City. It said the party personnel must be transferred to farm work and construction to meet Cuba's needs in the face of economic crisis. Soviet economic aid to Cuba hovers at $5 billion a year, and military aid is near the $1.5 billion mark, according to Western estimates. But economic hard times in the Soviet Union are expected to mean an aid reduction decision during January trade talks. The Kremlin maintains it will stand by Castro politically. But Castro's unflagging rejection of Soviet-style reform may influence the national Supreme Soviet legislature when it comes to debating a foreign aid bill. ``If they (Cubans) continue the so-called `old course,' we'll let them continue. But foreign aid won't be as it was before,'' said Nikolai V. Neyland, a member of the Supreme Soviet's Foreign Affairs Committee. Prensa Latina quoted Castro as saying that two-thirds of the Cuban Communist Party's officials were recently cut from the ranks and reported that parliament president Juan Escalona invited lawmakers' suggestions on how to trim away moreof them. ``The goal is to propose to the Cuban Communist Party's 4th congress how municipal governments should be structured and how many people can function efficiently,'' Escalona said. The scheduling of the congress, expected to result in constitutional reform sometime in the first half of 1991, is seen as an indication that Cuba needs to adjust its political trajectory. Castro has given a cold shoulder to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political reforms, undertaken in 1985. In turn, Gorbachev's ``new thinking'' on foreign affairs led him to state during a 1989 visit to Cuba that he opposes Castro's support for Communist revolutions in countries such as El Salvador, Angola and Nicaragua. The Soviets are also promoting a thaw in U.S.-Cuban relations, a 31-year antagonism that nearly led to nuclear war over the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. However, the official reason for cutting Soviet aid to Cuba is financial. Gorbachev's foreign aid bill proposes a 75 percent cut in ``gratuitous'' foreign economic aid, apparently for all Soviet allies. It envisions a new policy, starting Jan. 1, requiring allies to pay convertible currency at world prices for most trade with the Soviet Union. That would mean the end of favorable trade terms to Cuba as well as Vietnam, North Korea, Ethiopia and other countries. Meanwhile, more than 100,000 supporters of the Communist Youth Guild held a rally in Havana Friday in support of Castro, Prensa Latina said. Castro's Cuban revolution marks its 32nd anniversary on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Dentist in AIDS Case Accused of Using False Names
DOC.TEXT: A dentist gave a false name and occupation to doctors treating him for AIDS, contends a lawyer for a woman who says she contracted the deadly disease from him during dental surgery. Attorney David Eaton, who represents 22-year-old Kimberly Bergalis, made the allegation Friday during a hearing in her suit against CIGNA Dental Health of Florida Inc. The insurer put the late Dr. David Acer on its list of preferred dentists to be used by the company's clients. Bergalis claims Acer transmitted the disease to her during a September 1987 visit in which he removed two of her wisdom teeth. ``One defense being raised is that Acer was told he could continue treating patients,'' Eaton said. But Eaton said Acer, who died Sept. 1, didn't even tell the doctors treating him his real name. ``He said he was David Johnson, a real estate developer, so there's no way a doctor could have told him it was OK to continue treating patients,'' Eaton said. The dentist died two days after he wrote a letter to former patients urging them to be tested for AIDS, but expressing doubts they could have caught the disease from him. ``I consulted medical experts on whether I should continue practicing dentistry,'' Acer said in the letter. ``The experts advised me that as long as I followed the guidelines promulgated by the Center for Disease Control ... that I could safely continue to practice as a dentist and that I would not infect my patients.'' Continental National America Insurance Co. carried Acer's $1 million dental malpractice policy, which is the only asset of Acer's estate. Attorneys for both sides were in St. Lucie County Circuit Court on Friday for a hearing on whether Bergalis' attorneys are entitled to examine Acer's medical records from the Veterans Administration Hospital in Miami. Attorney Dennis Vandenberg, representing CNA, said Acer's parents don't want their son's family history and names of social contacts turned over to Eaton. Circuit Judge Robert Makemson gave the VA until Jan. 11 to turn over all medical records, including Acer's family and social history.

DOC.HEAD: Letter to Mandela Fails to Sway Boycott Leader
DOC.TEXT: A leader of a tourism boycott says the sending of a 2-year-old proclamation to Nelson Mandela fails to make up for what protesters see as a snub of the South African anti-apartheid leader. Metro-Dade Mayor Steve Clark sent a proclamation designating June 26, 1988, Nelson Mandela Day. Clark uncovered the little-known proclamation last weekend. Organizers of the 5-month-old tourism boycott want Metro-Dade, Miami Beach and Miami to each award Mandela a proclamation and keys to the city - honors denied him during his visit last June. ``Since your visit to Miami Beach last June,'' Clark wrote Mandela on Thursday, ``controversy and misunderstanding have developed over the lack of recognition given you by our local officials.'' The 2-year-old proclamation shows that ``the fight which you have waged for almost a quarter of a century in opposing the policies of apartheid in South Africa long has been recognized by myself and the people of Metropolitan Dade County,'' he said. Boycott organizer H.T. Smith said the action doesn't go far enough. ``The wrong occurred in 1990, and anything that happened before that does not redress the wrong done in 1990,'' Smith said. ``Because your boss gave you a raise in 1988 dos not at all make up for him unfairly snubbing you in 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Ryzhkov In Stable Condition Recovering From Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov remained in serious but stable condition after a heart attack earlier this week, the official Tass news agency reported today. Tass quoted an unidentified Health Ministry official as saying Ryzhkov's condition was not deteriorating, though the report did not specify when the official was interviewed. The prime minister suffered the heart attack Tuesday night. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited Central Clinical Hospital on Friday, talked to Ryzhkov's doctors and asked them to pass on his wishes for a speedy recovery, Tass said. Ryzhkov was not yet allowed to receive visitors. Ryzhkov experienced the heart attack the same day lawmakers voted to eliminate the Council of Ministers he heads. The Congress of People's Deputies voted to replace it with a new Cabinet under Gorbachev's direct control. It was unclear what role if any Ryzhkov might have in the revamped system.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Kills Self, Leaves Money to Suicide Foundation
DOC.TEXT: Money left to a right-to-die foundation will be used to market a 30-minute videotape on which a woman who committed suicide discusses her choice, the organization's administrator said. Lilian Stevens, who killed herself last July at age 84 while in failing health, bequeathed $32,000 to the My Choice organization she helped found. ``Mrs. Stevens and I think many people in this country have come to see the right to die as really a pro-choice issue, that a person should have the right to make this most personal decision,'' the Rev. John Brooke, a United Church of Christ minister and administrator for My Choice, said Friday. In the videotape, based on several hours of conversation with Brooke on Nov. 2, 1989, Stevens explained why she thought active euthanasia should be legal, said Brooke. The videotape, called ``Pro-Choice: From Womb to Tomb,'' also includes information on how to obtain a ``durable power of attorney for health care'' form, living will and other documents. The videotape also addresses arguments against the pro-choice philosophy, Brooke said. ``We talked about the danger of unscrupulous people misusing such a procedure if it were to be legalized,'' he said. Stevens was in failing health when she checked into a Monterey hotel and killed herself with pills and alcohol.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Asks for Reporter's Testimony
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reporter has been subpoenaed to testify about a jail-house interview conducted with a woman accused of shooting her husband to death. The Dayton Daily News requested Friday that the subpoena be thrown out. The newspaper cited the ``critical need to protect the news-gathering process from compelled disclosure.'' The subpoena was issued by Montgomery County Common Pleas Judge William MacMillan Jr. County Prosecutor Lee C. Falke also wants Dayton Daily News reporter Dwayne Bray to reveal the contents of notes he took during an interview with Joyce Anaga. In a story published Dec. 21 in the Daily News, Mrs. Anaga, 42, said her husband had abused her and that she shot him while they were struggling over a shotgun. She said she planned to plead self-defense under a new Ohio law for battered women. She goes on trial next week before MacMillan. Prosecutors said they want to see all of Mrs. Anaga's comments to Bray. ``If she takes the stand and gives a different story, then it would be very important to know if she said something different ... '' Falke said. Falke said there are precedents in Ohio courts that allow him to subpoena a reporter to answer questions about an interview. The Ohio Supreme Court ruled in June that a subpoena may be enforced ``over a reporter's claim of privilege, so long as it is persuaded that the subpoena has been requested or issued for a legitimate purpose, rather than for harassment.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Denies Secret Contacts With U.S. Over Kuwait
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's foreign minister today launched a new mediation effort in the Persian Gulf crisis on behalf of the 102-nation non-aligned movement. The move by Yugoslav Foreign Minister Budimir Loncar, who arrived in Baghdad Friday night, came 17 days away from the U.N. deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait or risk attack by the growing U.S.-led multinational force. Yugoslav diplomats said Loncar conferred today with Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, and was to meet President Saddam Hussein later in the day. Also today, the government denied reports of secret contacts with Washington, and Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Belousov left Baghdad after a four-day visit. Loncar's trip signaled an effort by the non-aligned movement to negotiate a settlement as the pressure on Saddam to relinquish the conquered emirate, now designated Iraq's 19th province, mounts daily. Yugoslavia is the current chairman of the group, which includes Kuwait and Iraq. The Yugoslav diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, declined to comment on reports that Loncar will discuss with Saddam details of a non-aligned peace initiative. Loncar last month visited Iran, the United Arab Emirates, Syria and Jordan for talks on the crisis. Aziz said before beginning discussions with Loncar that there has been no breakthrough in the stalemate over fixing a date for a proposed visit to Baghdad by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``No progress has so far been made on this issue,'' he told reporters. Both sides accuse the other of stalling. Saddam has said he is prepared for ``serious and constructive dialogue'' with the Americans, but diplomats see little sign of any meaningful talks between Washington and Baghdad. Iraq's information minister, Latif Nussayif Jassim, today denied reports of secret talks after Radio Monte Carlo quoted unidentified diplomatic sources in Cairo as saying Iraq was considering some ideas proposed by Washington. The radio said these include an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait in exchange for assuarnces that it will not be attacked by the multinational force that is expected to total more than half a million personnel by the end of January. ``These are ridiculous ideas and figments of the imagination,'' the official Iraqi News Agency quoted Jassim as saying. He reiterated the Iraqi position that there will be no pullout from Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. A U.N. Security Council resolution authorizes the use of force if Iraq does not withdraw by Jan. 15. The Iraqis appear adamant that any negotiations must include linkage between an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait with an Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab territory designed a Palestinian homeland. President Bush is equally adamant that there is no linkage. Belousov, the Soviet envoy, met Saddam Thursday. But no details of their talks have been released. In an interview with the semi-official al-Jomhuriya daily today, Belousov said they ``covered bilateral relations and issues of mutual interest, specially those related to the gulf crisis.'' Moscow has made repeated diplomatic efforts since the invasion to avert the threat of war. There was no indication whether Belousov's visit had any positive effect in this regard. Belousov told al-Jomhuriya that the majority of Soviet contract workers left in Iraq will leave before Jan. 10. Most of the 10,000 Soviet citizens who were stranded in Iraq at the outbreak of the crisis have already left. The Soviet embassy said 160 Soviets, employed mainly in oil and power installations, will be staying on. Amid the apparently faltering diplomatic campaign, the Iraqis stepped up preparations for war, with reports that special commando squads are being trained for behind-the-lines suicide attacks on American forces in Saudi Arabia. Al-Jomhuriya told Iraq's 17 million people today, particularly those in Baghdad and other cities, to be prepared for mock air raid warnings to test civil defense drills. Baghdad already staged mock drills this month. In another development that underlined Baghdad's isolation, the Iraqi News Agency reported that all Iraqi employees of the Arab League, including its Deputy Under-Secretary, Salah al-Moukhtar, have resigned in protest over the transfer of the league's headquarters to Cairo from Tunis. The transfer was approved by the majority of league members, including Egypt, which have denounced the invasion of Kuwait and which have joined the multinational force in Saudi Arabia. The headquarters was moved from Cairo in 1979, when Egypt's membership of the league was suspended because of its peace treaty with Israel. Egypt was allowed back into the Arab fold last year.

DOC.HEAD: Thirteen Die in Renewed Violence
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen people died in scattered nationwide violence following a Christmas lull, police said today. Four of those killed were victims of black factional fighting in eastern Natal Province, where more than 5,000 blacks have died in clashes in the past five years. The Inkatha Freedom Party, meanwhile, criticized plans by the rival African National Congress to intensify a mass action anti-apartheid campaign in Natal. A police unrest report distributed by the independent South African Press Association said 11 of the deaths occurred in Natal, the power base of Inkatha. The report, which covered the previous 24 hours, provided few details. Four people were killed and 11 houses set on fire near Greytown in what police described as a factional fight, which usually involves Inkatha supporters against blacks loyal to the ANC. The report said three of the victims were shot to death. Another four people died of stab wounds near Port Shepstone, the police report said. It provided no further information. The burned body of a black man was found near Port Shepstone, and two bodies with stab wounds were found near Creighton in Natal, the report said. Two people died when police fended off a stone-throwing mob by firing tear gas, service pistols and shotguns near Koster, 60 miles northwest of Johannesburg, the police report said. It said a police vehicle was damaged and one officer injured in the stoning. Inkatha and the ANC have been feuding for years over methods of fighting the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance. Inkatha is dominated by Zulus, and the ANC's main supporters are Xhosas. An Inkatha statement late Friday protested ANC plans for increased demonstrations, strikes and other mass action in Natal beginning Jan. 13. ``All their so-called mass actions have been organized on intimidation and coercion of people,'' the statement said. ``We in the Inkatha Freedom Party wish to warn the ANC that their program is a recipe for conflict, not peace.'' President F.W. de Klerk has pledged to eliminate apartheid and negotiate a new constitution that would give blacks political power. The white-led government and the ANC, the largest opposition group, have held talks aimed at setting up the constitutional negotiations. But chronic violence, usually vicious street fighting between ANC and Inkatha supporters, has strained the talks. The violence spread from Natal to Johannesburg-area black townships in August, an another 1,000 people have been killed since. The ANC blames Inkatha for the factional fighting, alleging Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi wants to broaden his power base beyond Natal, the traditional Zulu homeland. Inkatha accuses the ANC of trying to dominate the black opposition movement.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Revamps Cabinet; Drops Justice Minister Who Made Racial Remark
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to recast, UPDATE with more comment from Cabinet secretary. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today revamped his Cabinet, replacing his justice minister who drew fire for insulting American blacks. However, the departing justice minister received a powerful party post. Kaifu's 10-month-old Cabinet resigned earlier in the day under intense party pressure to allow other senior politicians in the governing Liberal Democratic Party to obtain prestigious government posts. But Kaifu scored a partial victory over powerful party kingpins by keeping out some scandal-tainted politicians. No major policy changes were expected, although both the minister of international trade and industry, Kabun Muto, and Agriculture Minister Tomio Yamamoto were replaced. The move could affect trade negotiations with the United States and other countries. Seventeen new members were named in the 21-member Cabinet. It was Kaifu's third Cabinet reshuffle since he rose from being a member of a weak party faction to prime minister in August 1989. The prime minister, however, succeeded in retaining principal Cabinet members, including Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto. ``Japan is facing mounting problems and we needed to maintain our continuity,'' Sakamoto, the principal government spokesman, told reporters. He cited Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's scheduled visit in April, the Persian Gulf crisis and strains in relations over trade. Prior to the Cabinet reshuffle, Kaifu's public ratings had been declining on charges of indecisiveness in responding to the gulf crisis. But the key question for Kaifu had been whether he possessed the clout to resist demands by senior party leaders to bring back politicians tainted by the Recruit influence-peddling scandal last year. The Recruit job-placement conglomerate had offered lucrative unlisted stock to influential politicians. Kaifu was named prime minister mostly because his ``Mr. Clean'' image positioned him as a compromise replacement for those affected by the scandal. None of the new Cabinet members had been connected with the Recruit scandal. Among those who will not be back is embattled Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, who again apologized for making racist remarks about American blacks that stirred outrage in the United States and other countries this fall. After touring a red-light district in Tokyo on Sept. 20, Kajiyama had compared foreign prostitutes in Japan to American blacks, saying they ``ruin the atmosphere of the neighborhoods they move into.'' ``I feel relieved now that I quit my post,'' Kajiyama said. However, shortly after resigning, he was appointed chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party's legislative affairs committee, an important post. The annual rotation of Cabinet posts has become a party tradition because lawmakers expect to assume a ministerial position after serving five or six terms in Parliament. Kaifu earlier said he would not announce a Cabinet change before Jan. 1 in an effort to display independence, but apparently changed his mind under pressure from party leaders. The governing party is comprised of five major factions, each headed by a powerful politician who aspires to become prime minister and to win Cabinet posts for his allies. Among the key new Cabinet members is the minister of international trade and industry, Eiichi Nakao, 60, an eight-term lawmaker who formerly served as director-general of the Economic Planning Agency. The new agriculture minister is Motoji Kondo, 60, a five-term lawmaker in his first Cabinet post.

DOC.HEAD: Cow's Output Saves Her From Slaughterhouse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `But now...', to correct misplaced `only', delete misspelled `its', correct style on personal pronouns of animals.
DOC.TEXT: At age 17, Robin the Holstein has lasted more than four times as long as most dairy cows. Now that she's finally retiring, her grateful owners wouldn't think of slaughtering her. ``She's a nice old cow. We're real proud of her,'' said owner Duane Hill. ``I'm going to let her die here on the farm and bury her in the front yard. We'll probably put a flower garden over her.'' Dairy cows are often slaughtered at age 4, Hill said, after being subjected to regimens under which they're quickly ``used up.'' But Robin has produced 35,000 gallons - or six tankers - of milk in a long career. Of the 65,000 dairy cows in Indiana whose production is monitored through the Dairy Herd Improvement Association, only one other living cow has equaled Robin's output, Hill said. But now Robin's getting old and producing only about 2 gallons a day. The cow bore her 13th calf last April and Hill said he won't try to breed her again. ``She's got a lot of gray in her hair. Her joints pop and crack and she's thin. It's taking all she can eat to take care of herself,'' he said Robin's offspring also proved good milk producers, earning Robin a Gold Medal Dam award from the National Holstein Association. Hill and his wife, Joyce Ann, milk 50 cows twice a day. They name all their cows and recognize their individual personalities. ``They're part of the family,'' Hill said.

DOC.HEAD: December To Be Record Month For Immigration; Housing Crisis Deepens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to RECAST; pickup 2nd graf pvs, `Some officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials say December will be a record month for immigration, setting off new debate on how to tackle the deepening housing crisis. About 40,00 newcomers are expected, most of them Soviet Jews. Some officials are urging the government take a greater role in housing construction. Others are calling for such stopgap measures as creating tent cities or putting newcomers in trailers atop buildings or in bomb shelters. December will be ``a record month in the history of immigration in Israel,'' Simcha Dinitz, head of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, told a news conference Friday. About 40,000 Jews are expected to immigrate to Israel this month, 35,000 of them from the Soviet Union, said Dinitz, whose agency assists the Israeli government in transporting and resettling immigrants. The pace of immigration has accelerated in recent weeks because of increasing political and economic uncertainty in the Soviet Union and better transportation arrangements by Israel, Dinitz told a news conference. The government expects more than 200,000 immigrants this year, about 90 percent of them Soviets. The total will be second only to 1949, when more than 239,000 immigrants arrived in the state created a year earlier. The flood of newcomers has put a severe strain on housing nationwide, driving up rents and forcing many families to double up in scarce units. Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz advocates purchasing tents to house up to 20 percent of the 400,000 Soviets expected next year. ``There will be no choice but (to adopt) this solution,'' he was quoted as saying Friday in the Hebrew newspaper Maariv. He noted that modern tents can be equipped with lights, heating and appliances. Dinitz rejected tents as an outdated response to a housing shortage. ``In 1990 I think ingenuity can find better accommodation than tents, especially in winter,'' Dinitz said, urging the installation of more mobile homes. Dinitz urged the government to take over construction. He said the government set aside funds this year for 45,000 new housing units, but only 27,000 had been started by private contractors. ``In the interim,'' he said, ``we will have to use public buildings, army camps, hostels, hotels - every available space.'' Israeli mayors have suggested immigrants be put in bomb shelters, and Housing Minister Ariel Sharon said Thursday that small mobile homes should be put on apartment house rooftops and in the back yards of houses to accommodate the crush. Soviets have been pouring into Israel since the spring of 1989, when the Soviet Union eased its policy on exit permits. The number has grown each month this year, and the government has ordered the El Al national airline to use every available plane for immigrants. This week, planes have been arriving at half-hour intervals from transit stops in Hungary, Romania and Poland. The government predicts that 1 million Soviets will arrive by the end of 1992, and Dinitz said the figure could exceed 2 million before the wave of immigration ends. The country's current population is about 4.5 million. Dinitz repeated the government's claim that it was not directing the new immigrants to settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. Many of the Arabs were forced from Israel when the state was created in 1948. He said only a few are settling there, he said, estimating the number at less than 0.5 percent. His estimate did not include Arab east Jerusalem, captured with the West Bank in the 1967 Middle East war and later annexed by Israel. An estimated 4,500 Soviets now live in the Arab sector of the city, according to Western diplomats. Palestinians have opposed the Soviet immigration, fearing they will be displaced and arguing that Israel will be less inclined to give up the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Aligned Leader Holds Talks; Britain Plans Germ Warfare Inoculations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Yugoslav foreign minister meeting with Aziz, Syrian foreign minister dismissing Arab solution, Iraqi official denying report of U.S. contacts. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq met today with the foreign minister of Yugoslavia, a representative of the world's non-aligned nations, to discuss ways to avert war, diplomats said. Iraq denied it has had secret diplomatic contacts with the United States. Britain said it would inoculate its gulf troops against biological weapons, following a similar U.S. announcement. The meeting in Baghdad between Yugoslavia's foreign minister and his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz, came 17 days ahead of the U.N. deadline for Iraq to end its occupation of Kuwait or face possible war. Yugoslavia, leader of the 102-nation non-aligned movement, appeared to be launching a new mediation effort. The Yugoslav official, Budimir Loncar, was also scheduled to meet with Saddam Hussein, Yugoslav diplomats said on condition of anonymity. Loncar visited Iran, the United Arab Emirates, Syria and Jordan last month for talks. Previous attempts at mediation have failed but this new initiative had at least one distinction: Both Iraq and Kuwait belong to the non-aligned movement, which rejects any formal military alliances with East or West. Iraq's information minister, Latif Nussayif Jassim, today denied a report of secret U.S.-Iraqi contacts to avert a conflict, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Radio Monte Carlo quoted unidentified diplomatic sources in Egypt as saying Iraq was considering some ideas proposed by Washington. The radio said these include an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait in exchange for assurances that it will not be attacked by the U.S.-led multinational force that is expected to total more than half a million troops by the end of January. ``These are ridiculous ideas and figments of the imagination,'' Jassim was quoted as saying. The United States and Iraq remain at an impasse over dates for direct talks. Iraq had invited Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit on Jan. 12, but the Bush administration say that is too close to the Jan. 15 deadline. Washington has said any Baker-Saddam meeting must take place before Thursday. In other developments: -Vice President Dan Quayle was scheduled to leave late today for a New Year's visit to U.S. troops sent to the gulf region since Iraq invaded Kuwait nearly five months ago. Quayle's intinerary included trips to military outposts in the Saudi Arabian desert. -Iraqi media reported up to 300,000 paramilitary troops in the Kurdish region have been reactivated to shore up the country's northern border with Turkey, part of the multinational coalition against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. -Lloyd's shipping intelligence has advised vessels off Saudi Arabia's northern gulf coast to use ``extreme caution'' after two drifting mines were found earlier this week near the Zuluf oil field. The Friday report did not say who detected and destroyed the mines. -A 66-year-old Swedish peace activist was hospitalized in Oman for a heart condition after U.S. forces intercepted an Iraqi ship she was aboard in the Arabian Sea. Omani Health Ministry officials said Margaret Andersson was on a cardiac monitor in a hospital after the U.S. Navy airlifted her from the freighter. She reportedly suffered chest pains after the boarding, which was condemned by Baghdad. The freighter was carrying sugar and other goods in violation of a U.N. embargo on Iraq. British and U.S. military officials have not given details of plans to inoculate troops against biological weapons, which are germs used to carry diseases such as cholera, anthrax and typhoid. About 21,000 British civilians in the gulf region will also receive gas masks, officials said. CIA Director William Webster has said Iraq has stockpiles of germs, which can be delivered on warheads or by low-flying planes. Iraq has denied the allegations. Some of the problems facing the inoculation program is the wide variety of vaccines needed and the month or more needed for some vaccines to take effect, military and medical analysts said. The British government on Friday ordered 390 army meical reservists sent to the gulf after too few volunteers came forward. It is the first military conscription in Britain since forces were sent to Cyprus, Borneo and Aden in 1965. Saddam has sent an estimated 500,000 troops to southern Iraq and Kuwait since he seized the emirate on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed, More Than 100 Wounded In Gaza Riots
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops shot and killed four Palestinians, of them two teen-agers, and wounded more than 100 in a series of violent clashes in the occupied Gaza Strip today, Israeli and Arab reports said. The violence in the town of Gaza and the Rafah refugee camp began in the afternoon after troops killed two masked Arab activists who were caught writing slogans on the wall and refused to obey the soldiers' orders to stop, Israel radio and Palestinian journalists said. The two were identified as 16-year-old Osama Ismail el-Bulbeisi and 19-year-old Islam Harb. Arab accounts said both were shot in the head. When news of the deaths spread in Rafah, an angry Palestinian mob pelted the soldiers with stones. Troops fired, killing another two Arabs, the radio said. The reports said more than 100 people were wounded. The army command earlier said there were ``local disturbances'' in the refugee camps of Jabaliya and Khan Yunis. In Khan Yunis, three firebombs were also hurled at Israeli soldiers. No injuries were reported. Israeli officials have predicted there would be a surge in the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza, linking it to Tuesday's ``Fatah Day.'' It marks the 26th anniversary of the first anti-Israeli attack by Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization. In the raid on Jan. 1, 1965, a Fatah guerrilla squad infiltrated Israel and placed a small bomb at the country's National Water Carrier. One guerrilla was later killed in a clash with the Jordanian army. At least 781 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians in the revolt. An additional 322 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Fifty-seven Israelis have also been slain in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Shells Villages, Killing Four, After Rocket Attack
DOC.TEXT: Police said Israeli gunners shelled Shiite Moslem villages in the Syrian-policed Bekaa Valley today, killing four children and wounding three people. Israel said the shelling was in response to an attack with Soviet-made Katyusha rockets, apparently launched from north of Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon. The army command in Jerusalem said the rockets, which landed in the security zone or in Israel, caused no injuries or damage. The Lebanese police said the Israeli artillery barrage came at midday and hit the villages of Mashghara, Sohmor, Maydoun and Ein el-Tineh, two miles north of the security zone. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations, said the slain children were three brothers and a girl, ranging in age from 1 to 4. He said the three wounded adults, all civilians, were reported to be in critical condition. Israel carved out the 440-square-mile security zone in 1985 after a three-year occupation of southern Lebanon. The zone is designed to protect Israel's northern border from guerrilla infiltration and is patrolled by Israel and its militia allies of the South Lebanon Army, a mainly Christian force.

DOC.HEAD: Sweep Nets 21 Mafia Suspects in Rome and Sicily
DOC.TEXT: Police swept through Rome, Catania and other Italian cities before dawn Saturday, arresting 21 people suspected of involvement in a Mafia-run drug, extortion and loan-sharking operation, officers said. The roundup by the carabinieri, Italy's paramilitary police, also turned up equipment apparently used by the suspects to monitor police communications, according to a statement from the force's headquarters in Rome. In all, 31 arrest warrants were issued following an investigation that sprang from the murder in September in Rome of a suspected mob boss from a clan in Catania, eastern Sicily, police said. The Italian news agency ANSA said that seven of those named in the warrants were already in jail. Police said they confiscated 33 pounds of hashish.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Cosmonauts To Celebrate Russian Christmas With Space Walk
DOC.TEXT: Two Soviet cosmonauts will spend the Russian Christmas on Jan. 7 walking in space, Tass reported Saturday. Viktor Afanasyev and Musa Manarov will make another attempt to repair a broken hatch on a module attached to the orbiting Mir space station, the official Soviet news agency said. Two other cosmonauts spent a grueling seven hours in space in July trying to repair a torn thermal insulation on their Soyuz TM-9 capsule, only to discover they could not close the hatch leading back to the space station. Soviet media reported at the time they were dangerously close to running out of oxygen, although the cosmonauts later denied they had any problems. They were able to close the hatch on a subsequent space walk, but Tass said it continues to cause problems. Afanasyev and Manarov took the first journalist into space on their Dec. 2 launch, Toyohiro Akiyama of Japan's TBS television network. Akiyama returned to Earth eight days later with the outgoing cosmonauts.

DOC.HEAD: Chess Champion Kasparov Named Soviet Athlete Of The Year
DOC.TEXT: World chess champion Garry Kasparov, who successfully defended his title in an exhausting two-month series with Anatoly Karpov, has been named the Soviet Union's top athlete of 1990, Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said skier Yelena Vualbe, a two-time world champion, was ranked second in the annual poll of Soviet sportswriters. Tennis player Andrei Cherkasov and soccer player Sergei Yuran were next, followed by weightlifter Anatoly Khrapty, Tass said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Time: The `Two Sides Of George Bush' Chosen As `Men' Of Year
DOC.TEXT: President Bush was named Time magazine's 1990 man of the year, the magazine announced today. Or rather, the ``two sides of President Bush'' were dubbed the ``men of the year'' by the magazine, which praised Bush's foreign policy work while criticizing his domestic role. Each year, the magazine chooses as its woman or man of the year a person who for better or for worse has the most impact on the year's events. This year, Time said it chose to feature the two faces of President Bush on the cover of its Jan. 7 issue, which hits newsstands Monday, because he fits both aspects of the magazine's definition. On foreign policy, Bush ``was a study in resoluteness and mastery'' while domestically he was ``just as strongly marked by wavering and confusion.'' The magazine credited Bush for having ``raised a vision of a new world order'' with his leadership in the creation of the embargo and military buildup against Iraq that puts him in a position to have a ``favorable impact on the course of events.'' Meanwhile, domestically Bush has left ``things alone until he could no longer avoid taking action.'' The two sides of Bush show what interests him, according to the magazine. ``Global diplomacy is what he has trained for and what absorbs him; domestic affairs are just not as much fun,'' Time said. In an interview with Time, Bush blamed the Democratic-controlled Congress for stalling his domestic plans. ``To accomplish things, you have first got to beat down the Democrats. And that's not true in foreign affairs,'' Bush said. About Iraq, Bush said his gut feeling is that Saddam Hussein will withdraw from Kuwait. ``But that flies in the face of what some of the Arab leaders tell me, which is that he cannot get out. He cannot do in Kuwait what he did in Iran. He cannot do it and survive domestically,'' Bush said. Four others cited by Time as among the year's most important newsmakers were Saddam, Nelson Mandela, Helmut Kohl and Boris Yeltsin. Bush is the ninth U.S. president or president-elect to be selected for the Man of the Year issue. The others are Franklin D. Roosevelt, 1932, 1934 and 1941; Harry S. Truman, 1945 and 1948; Dwight D. Eisenhower, 1959 (also selected in 1944, before he became president); John F. Kennedy in 1961; Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964 and 1967; Richard M. Nixon, winner in 1971 and co-winner in 1972 with Henry Kissinger; President-elect Jimmy Carter in 1976; and Ronald Reagan, winner as president-elect in 1980 and co-winner with Yuri Andropov in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, More than 180 Injured in Northeast Transit Accidents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and subs 11-12th grafs, `The dead...', with 3 grafs to UPDATE with woman dying. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Transit police...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4, BX2
DOC.TEXT: Authorities blamed the first snowstorm of the season for an electrical fire that trapped four rush-hour trains in a smoke-filled subway tunnel, killing one person and injuring 150 others. A second rider died of her injuries today. In Boston, authorities investigating a trolley accident that injured 33 people Friday said tests showed the trolley driver had high levels of alcohol in his system. It was the second rail accident this month in the city's Back Bay section. The driver of the trolley, which rammed a streetcar that was unloading passengers, blamed faulty brakes for the collision, officials said. But investigators ruled that out as a possible cause, said Peter Dimond, spokesman for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The fire Friday morning in New York filled trains with smoke in a subway tunnel linking Manhattan and Brooklyn. Fire and transit officials said melting snow from a 7-inch snowfall overnight apparently caused an electrical short-circuit. Passengers heard explosions and then saw smoke, first pouring into the tunnel and then into their trains. ``We really thought we were gone, that we wouldn't see New Year's,'' said Gertrude Hoyte, a 51-year-old Brooklyn resident trapped in the tunnel. Some people began vomiting into their newspapers, she said. ``People were screaming, `We're going to die!''' and others prayed out loud, said 28-year-old Dana Sullivan. Andrew Rea, 29, said that as smoke began filling the train, it ``got so bad you couldn't see halfway down the car.'' ``A lot of people passed out,'' said Naomi Smalls-Watson, 23. Transit Authority spokeswoman Caren Gardner said the exact cause was unclear, but that snow may have fallen onto the electrified third rail and caused an electrical cable to short. The dead man was identified by Transit Police spokesman Al O'Leary as Peter Hagen, 35, of Smithtown. The cause of death was under investigation. Another rider, a 37-year-old Massapequa Park woman, died this morning at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, said said nursing supervisor Adriene Kushner. Se had been revived at the hospital Friday after appearing dead at the scene. Authorities said 150 people were injured, including some police and firefighters. Injuries ranged from smoke inhalation to cuts and bruises. Transit Police Capt. Michael Ansbro said 300 to 400 people were on the 10-car train that carried most of the injured. Fire Commissioner Carlos M. Rivera said the accident couldn't have been prevented. ``It's something that is beyond our control - nature does what nature wants to do.'' Boston's Green Line trolley crash occurred during morning rush hour when one trolley rammed the rear of a second parked in the underground Arlington Street station. Transit officials said each had about 40 people aboard. ``The driver in the rear car, the car that did the hitting ... a 20-year veteran, was found to test positive for alcohol,'' Dimond said. The 64-year-old driver, whose name was not released, was suspended without pay pending the outcome of the investigation, Dimond said. Dimond declined to specify the driver's blood-alcohol content, but said it was ``high.'' He said investigators had ruled out brake failure and the signal system as possible causes. Ernest Jones, a passenger on the stationary trolley, said one minute he was reading his newspaper, the next the lights were out and he saw at least four people bleeding from head injuries. ``I was looking at the lady across from me, next thing I knew the lights went out and she was on the floor,'' he said. ``I saw one man in the back on the floor on his back, crying, obviously in agony, hurt.'' Most of the injured people were treated and released at area hospitals. One was seriously hurt and taken to New England Medical Center and another was admitted to University Hospital. More than 260 people were injured Dec. 12 when an Amtrak train derailed in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Vaccinating Against Germ Warfare a Long Shot
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's plan to inoculate troops in the Persian gulf against germ warfare agents is a medical roll of the dice, because no single vaccine works against all of the hundreds of microbes that could be used in a biological attack, experts say. For a military force to be immune to any such assault, the troops would have to be vaccinated weeks or even months in advance and the vaccines used would have to exactly match the microbes used in the attack, the medical authorities say. ``With most vaccines it takes from two to four weeks to develop adequate immune protection,'' said Dr. Bradley Sack, a Johns Hopkins University expert on infectious diseases. And, often, he said, full protection for some specific diseases could take up to several months. To develop immunity, the body of each soldier would have to be exposed to a vaccine and then have time to build up the billions of antibodies needed to repel the disease. If vaccinations of U.S. forces don't start until next week, Sack said, it is unlikely that the troops would all have developed the full immunity needed by Jan. 15, the U.N.-set date for Iraq to pull out of Kuwait or face military action. U.S. military officials refuse to identify any particular disease for which troops will be vaccinated. But published reports have said that Iraq's biological arsenal may include these diseases: typhoid, cholera, anthrax, rabbit fever and botulism. This group, says Dr. Sanford Kuvin, vice chairman of the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases, ``is only the short list'' of possibilities. ``If you restrict the biological warfare possibilities to the short list of common things, it could probably be dealt with in a moderately effective way by the U.S. military,'' he said. But the real problem, said Kuvin, is that nature has provided so many microbe warriors that can be marshaled into armies. ``The menu of lethality is very long,'' said Kuvin. ``There are innumerable viral diseases. And I don't know how you could make a cocktail of vaccines that would be effective against them all.'' And there are problems even with the ``short list.'' There is a vaccine for anthrax, the most popular candidate named by experts as a possible biological weapon. But the vaccine is not commercially available and few American doctors, even in the military, have ever dealt with it. ``There's very little of that disease in this country,'' said Sack. But another expert, who asked not to be named, said that the military is thought to have developed an anthrax vaccine designed for use in combat situations. Cholera, another disease candidate on the short list, has virtually no effective vaccine. Sack said there is an experimental oral vaccine that has been tested in Bangladesh, but it has not been tried in this country. ``I've heard that the military may want to use it,'' he said. ``Of the little we have, it seems to be the most effective. It takes at least three doses over a month.'' For typhoid, there is an oral vaccine that provides 65 to 70 percent protection with few side effects. It requires four doses over eight days and immunity is good within 10 days of the last dose, said Sack. Science has no vaccine for rabbit fever, or tularemia. Neither is there one for botulism, the common food-borne bacteria. Both diseases can be fatal, but both will respond to antibiotics. Kuvin said, however, the biological weapons that are of most concern to him are the hundreds of microbes that are rarely or never seen in the United States, but which could be devastating to American troops. There are organisms, he said, that spring up from Africa or Asia or South America, wipe out large populations and then burn themselves out, only to pop up again years later somewhere else. They bear names like Blue Nile virus, Rift Valley fever, Marburg virus, dengue fever or lassa fever. ``Some of these are almost universally lethal,'' said Kuvin. And there is no proven vaccine for many of them. And even if there were vaccines for them all, which should American troops be protected against? That, said the experts, is the military and biological gamble. If the Americans choose correctly, then the U.S. troops would be protected. But if the soldiers are inoculated for one group of diseases and then are attacked with weapons containing a totally different disease, the results, said Kuvin, could be ``devastating.'' The physician, however, said all of these factors are well-known to the Army experts who have studied biological warfare for years. ``I know, for a fact, that the Army has the best microbe hunters in the world,'' said Kuvin. ``If anyone does, they have the experts to solve the problems we have discussed.''

DOC.HEAD: War or Peace? That's What Waits for Congress on Thursday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after 7th graf, `That debate ..., to update with Bush to meet with congressional leaders Thursday. Originally moved in advance Dec. 27 as b0538.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For the new Congress convening on Thursday, the questions of peace and war are waiting, with added urgency as the days dwindle toward the Jan. 15 for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Five months of intermittent debate and a dozen House and Senate hearings have produced no answers and scant guidance to define the role of the Democratic Congress in a crisis under Republican management. At this point, it's a crisis on hold for the holidays. At a quiet Capitol, recorded telephone messages report some offices closed until after the New Year. President Bush is at Camp David, Md., on an 11-day break. There's little traffic and less tension in the capital, even as reinforcements are deployed in the Persian Gulf and the Saudi Arabian desert, building to the troop strength that could deliver on the U.S. threat to take the offensive after mid-January. That's when the United Nations has authorized the use of force if necessary. According to the Democratic leaders of Congress, U.S. forces cannot be sent to fight without congressional approval. According to the Republican administration, Bush already has all the authority he needs to act. That debate will resume when Congress does. It won't be conclusive. The answer has been elusive for two centuries under a constitutional system that makes the president the commander in chief and empowers only Congress to declare war. Bush has met with congressional leaders several times over the Gulf crisis, and, according to Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, will do so again Thursday, as soon as the new Congress is sworn in. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney and Secretary of State James A. Baker III also are expected to participate in the sessions. There were demands during the fall that Congress be summoned back to declare war. There were calls for a resolution of approval for Bush's policy of threatening military action against Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. There were proposals to invoke the creaky machinery of the war powers system, under which a president can't send troops into danger unless Congress approves. None of that happened, and none of it is likely to happen now. But in one form or another, the 102nd Congress is going to have to come to clear, majority decisions on the Persian Gulf, possibly but not necessarily on direct questions of policy, certainly on the money and manpower to back up that policy. The administration will need a supplemental appropriation of up to $20 billion early this year to finance Operation Desert Shield. Call-up authority for some support units summoned to active duty will begin expiring in March unless Congress extends it or Bush declares a national emergency. And there may have to be action later in the year to change the timetable for cutbacks that are supposed to reduce active duty military forces by at least 80,000 before next Sept. 30. An attempt to write a policy resolution and get it through House and Senate would be risky for both Congress and the White House. Bush has been quoted as telling members of Congress that he would welcome a resolution of support, along the lines of the United Nations resolution authorizing force after Jan. 15, but ``if you're going to debate this for months and not reach a conclusion and argue about it, then that may not be helpful ... '' Resolutions endorsing his policy were adopted by overwhelming votes in the House and Senate early in October, backing ``continued action by the president ... to deter Iraqi aggression and protect American lives and vital interests.'' But the authors of those measures said they covered only what had been done to that point, and did not authorize the use of force. When those measures passed, the strategy for forcing Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait was built around economic sanctions against Iraq, with the United States assigned to defend Saudi Arabia against any attack by Saddam Hussein's forces. On Nov. 8, Bush ordered U.S. forces doubled, to create the capability and raise the possibility of military action to retake Kuwait. Democratic leaders were told of the decision shortly before Bush announced it. And support that had been almost unanimous began to fray, with Democrats urging patience, to give economic sanctions more time to work. But Democrats can't risk becoming the party of dissent while American forces are at risk. That could weaken the U.S. position in the current confrontation, at a time when Bush says the best way to avoid war is to convince Saddam Hussein that he faces war unless he relents. And it could do them lasting political damage. Vice President Dan Quayle produced a preview of a Republican counterattack, saying earlier this month that ``patience at any price'' would amount to appeasement of Saddam Hussein. As the debate resumes, Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader, says whatever the differences on timing and tactics, the United States is united on the goal of getting Iraq out of Kuwait. The question is how. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.
