DOC.HEAD: Time Magazine Names the Two Sides of George Bush Men of Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to recast and ADD that issue hits newsstands Monday. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, `One is a ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's resoluteness in foreign affairs in contrast to his ``wavering and confusion'' over domestic policies made him Time magazine's two-faced man of the year in 1990. Time said Saturday that the ``two sides of President Bush'' will be presented in the cover story of its Jan. 7 issue, which hits newsstands Monday. One is a leader whose foreign policy during the year ``was a study in resoluteness and mastery,'' the magazine said Saturday. The other is a leader whose domestic track record was ``just as strongly marked by wavering and confusion.'' ``We did something a little unusual this year, a little unorthodox,'' Time Managing Editor Henry Muller said at a news conference. The magazine said Bush ``raised a vision of a new world order'' by taking the lead in a United Nations embargo against Iraq and a military buildup in the Persian Gulf after Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait in early August. But domestically, Bush left ``things alone until he could no longer avoid taking action,'' Time said. ``Global diplomacy is what he has trained for and what absorbs him; domestic affairs are just not as much fun,'' Time said. Bush narrowly defeated Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for the Man of the Year title, Muller said. ``Why didn't we pick Saddam? The answer in the end really is that invading a little country is not enough to make you man of the year,'' Muller said. Others cited as some of the year's most important newsmakers were South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic. Every president since Franklin D. Roosevelt has been selected by the magazine as its man of the year.

DOC.HEAD: First Woman to Command Navy Ship Says Gender Not an Issue
LaserPhoto ROM2
DOC.TEXT: Although a tenth of the U.S. Navy's officers are women, Lt. Cmdr. Darlene M. Iskra last week became the first to captain her own ship. She'll be even happier, she says, when women are allowed into battle. ``Women are in every aspect of naval duties today,'' Iskra said Saturday. ``We're limited in the type of ship that we may board, but that might change, and I hope it does.'' Women are not permitted to serve aboard combat ships. Iskra, 38, was installed Thursday night as commander of the USS Opportune, a salvage ship with a 98-member, all-male crew. She replaced Cmdr. Edgar J. Jones, who flew to the United States from the U.S. Sixth Fleet base in Naples for emergency medical treatment. Iskra had been scheduled to replace Jones on Jan. 24. ``My being a woman is just not an issue. I'm different from Cmdr. Jones, but if I was a male I would be different from him too,'' she said. ``It's geat,'' she said of her assignment. ``It's the best thing I've ever done.'' Iskra, of South San Francisco, Calif., is a special operations officer and the Navy's most senior female diving officer, though she won't be doing much diving as the Opportune's commander. Before her assignment to the USS Opportune, Iskra was second-in-command of the USS Preserver, based in Little Creek, Va. After earning a bachelor's degree at San Francisco State University, she entered the Navy's officer candidate school in Newport, R.I. in March 1979. ``I've always liked the ocean,'' she said. ``My father tried to join the Navy when he was 16, but he was under age. It was during World War II and they kicked him out. He joined the Merchant Marine instead.'' Crew members said there had been little negative reaction to Iskra's appointment. ``You must respect the uniform and the rank, regardless of who's behind them,'' said Bill Watterson, a senior chief petty officer from Norfolk, Va. ``It's going to cause some of us to be more careful of our so-called sailor talk,'' he added with a grin. The Opportune, currently on a five-month tour, recovers equipment or the wreckage of ships from the sea and sometimes tows disabled vessels. The ship will not enter combat zones but could be stationed somewhere outside the Persian Gulf to help in the event of a war, said Lt. Scott Campbell, a Navy public information officer in Naples. Iskra's appointment is to last 30 months. Iskra's husband and fellow Navy diver, Lt. Cmdr. Marc J. Thomas, is the commanding officer of a special boat unit in Norfolk, Va.

DOC.HEAD: New President, Vice President Sworn In After Suriname Coup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 9th `National Assembly...' to ADD that chairman of assembly declared nominees to be accepted; pickup graf 10 `Several of....'
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly confirmed the army's choice for president Saturday without a vote, and some members stormed out of the chamber in protest. The new president was sworn in five days after the military threw out President Ramsewak Shankar in a bloodless coup and pledged to install a ``non-political'' interim cabinet and organize a popular vote. Shankar had been locked in a bitter dispute with former army commander Cmdr. Desi Bouterse, who ruled Suriname as dictator from 1980-1988. The main purpose of the new government will be to organize elections within 100 days, according to the military. The new president, Johan Kraag, in his late 70s, belongs to the National Party of Suriname. Ousted Vice President Henck Arron is a member of the same party. Jules Wijdenbosch was also sworn in as the new vice president. He is a former prime minister who organized Suriname's last popular elections in 1987, which Shankar won. Wijdenbosch is chairman of the National Democratic Party, which was organized by Bouterse. One National Assembly member, Arti Jesurun, vice president of the National Party of Suriname, said on Surinamese radio there had been an agreement for a secret ballot, but the rules were reversed Saturday. ``As far as I am concerned, the National Assembly approved the new president and vice president with bowed heads,'' Jesurun said. National Assembly Chairman Jaggernath Lathmon said that under Surinamese tradition, no vote was necessary because there was only one candidate for each office. He declared the nominees to be unanimously approved without a vote. Several of the 51 members at the session stormed out of the chamber, leaving 34 members on the assembly floor. Had a vote taken place, at least two-thirds - 34 votes - were needed for approval. Shankar and his Cabinet formally submitted their resignations to the National Assembly on Thursday. The military claims that Suriname's constitution permits military intervention as long as the National Assembly is left intact. This ethnically diverse nation of 400,000 people on the northeast coast of South America has suffered progressive economic decline since 1980, the year that Bouterse rose to power in a coup. Shankar's overthrow coincided with growing popular discontent with his government's inability to revive the economy of this former Dutch colony, beset by high inflation and unemployment. The government has a monthly trade deficit of $10 million. Bouterse stepped down as army chief just hours before the latest coup in the culmination of a long-running dispute with Shankar. He is widely believed to have planned the coup. In Washington, the Organization of American States on Friday denounced the military takeover. The United States joined in the protest. Domestic opposition to the takeover has been muted, although the daily De Ware Tyd on Friday accused the army of ``imposing its will on the government.'' Bouterse still remains the most powerful army figure in the country as chairman the Military Authority, which supervised the armed forces. He resigned as army chief, but that resignation is expected to be reviewed by the new government, the army has stated.

DOC.HEAD: New Attitude Tops Annual List of Resolutions
DOC.TEXT: An attitude adjustment is more important in preventing disease than changes in diet and exercise habits, the American Institute for Preventive Medicine says in its New Year's resolutions list. The No. 1 entry on the institute's sixth annual ``Top Ten Healthiest Resolutions'' list is to avoid ``psychosclerosis'' - a hardening of the attitudes, Dr. Don Powell, president of the institute, said Friday. ``It's the way we view the events in life,'' he said. ``We used to think physical fitness was from the neck down, but now we see it as more of an integration of mind and body.'' Powell, author of ``365 Health Hints,'' said working out at the gym isn't enough for people who want to live longer, healthier lives. ``You have to look at their attitude, the way they deal with stress, whether they have a social support network, and the way they view life,'' he said. Adopting the resolutions on the list, which is based on recent medical research, could add up to 20 years to a person's life, Powell said. The list includes traditional good-health commandments like watch weight, reduce cholesterol, get physical, control blood pressure, limit alcohol and use seat belts. It also includes resolutions to control hostility and develop a social support network. Stop smoking appears on the 1991 list as it has each year since 1985, but this year's list includes a resolution to avoid smokers to escape the potentially harmful effects of passive smoke outlined in a recent U.S. Surgeon General's report. Thomas Lauria, spokesman for the Washington-based Tobacco Institute, said that that resolution suggests segregating 30 percent of the population and would foster unnecessary ill will. ``We're seeing a 90's version of the new segregationist,'' Lauria said. ``Imagine if you put any other group in that category, like don't associate with Catholics. Can you imagine the outbreak that would cause?'' Resolutions to get at least seven hours of sleep each night was bumped off the list for 1991 to make room for the attitude adjustment priority. Other past resolutions include seeking the medicinal values of laughter, avoiding loneliness and practicing safe sex. ``That's not to say safe sex isn't a critical issue in our time, too, but the mental health issues take precedent,'' Powell said.

DOC.HEAD: Freeze Lingers in Plains, Fog Shrouds East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `No other...' to UPDATE with four traffic deaths in Oklahoma. Picks up 15th graf, `By afternoon ...' ^By DOUGLAS J. ROWE
DOC.TEXT: Frigid air threatened what was left of California's ravaged citrus crop Saturday, and parts of the East were in a fog as temperatures rose and the snow that fell just a day earlier melted, making roads slushy and slippery. Temperatures rose on both coasts, but the Dakotas, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming and Utah stayed in a deep freeze. ``In the coldest areas, farmers will suffer more crop damage,'' Betty Reo of the National Weather Service in California said. Daytime temperatures on Sunday could reach 60 in Los Angeles and the 50s in San Francisco, but growers could battle temperatures in the 20s in inland areas throughout the state overnight, the weather service said. That prompted concern over crops that escaped the first cold blitz and the future of the groves themselves. ``What a lot of growers are concerned about this weekend is how much tree damage they'll have,'' said Tom McNair of the state Department of Food and Agriculture. The San Joaquin Valley, the state's major orange growing area, saw its navel orange crop virtually destroyed last weekend as temperatures sank into the low 20s and the teens. The loss has been estimated at up to $288 million. One day after Pennsylvania residents struggled with snow up to 16 inches deep, they encountered another hurdle to driving - fog. ``The whole state's pretty much blanketed in fog,'' Doug Young, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service, said Saturday morning. The fog is produced by warm air moving over the cold snow, causing the snow to evaporate, he said. Visibility in many places this morning ranged from a half-mile to zero. ``It could make driving hazardous, especially since there's a lot of slush on the road already,'' Young said. ``Everything seems to be the same color.'' In south-central Pennsylvania, freezing rain caused numerous accidents, police said. A 10-year-old Chambersburg boy was killed and his brother was critically injured in a traffic accident caused by ice on the road Friday night before the fog set in. Icy roads in Oklahoma were blamed for the deaths Saturday of four people, including a Houston man, in three car crashes. There have been more than 90 weather-related deaths since the wave of cold began Dec. 18. By afternoon, the fog thinned, and temperatures reached the 40s and 50s, melting most of the snowpack. More rain also was forecast, raising the possibility of flooding. Frigid temperatures enveloped Montana on Saturday, with Butte reporting the nation's lowest temperature - 36 degrees below zero. Arctic air swept in by a strong north wind plunged Nebraska into a deep freeze with wind chills down to 58 below zero at Columbus. ``It's colder than the devil,'' said Bill Joseph, owner of the Pepper Mill Cafe in Valentine, the coldest spot in the state at 20 degrees below zero. ``A lot of people's cars won't start today,'' he said. ``Some people had theirs plugged in and it still wouldn't start.'' The second winter storm that hit Washington state in two weeks battered beaches as well as inland areas and emergency officials said as many as 10 waterfront homes on Puget Sound have been destroyed or damaged by storm waves. About three dozen more were threatened by water after bulkheads were washed out. The water damage was part of the windstorm that whipped into Washington early Friday, with frigid temperatures and some snow. One woman on Vashon Island was killed by a falling tree. About 150,000 utility customers in western Washington were without electricity at one time. Puget Sound Power and Light spokeswoman Heidi Dunlap said 52,000 customers were still without power Saturday morning. She said crews hoped to have service restored by Sunday night. No power meant no heat, so three shelters were set up. About 300 people spent the night in them. Authorities also worked in below-zero temperatures Saturday to restore power to Ortonville in western Minnesota, a town of about 2,600 residents. In Arkansas, anticipated showers provoked the National Weather Service to issue a flash flood watch for the southeastern two-thirds of the state. The weather service issued a flood warning Saturday for northwest, north-central and west-central Indiana after more than 1{ inches of rain fell in areas. New Year's Day will bring some good news to Southern California, said forecasters, who foresee picture-perfect weather for the Rose Parade and Rose Bowl game with highs in the upper 60s. And in Philadelphia, most of the snow was expected to melt by Sunday, so it should not interfere with the annual Mummer's Parade on New Year's Day.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Keeps Money hopes Alive With Win
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to CLARIFY score after Saturday's game and tighten. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Karpov kept his hopes alive for a 50-50 cut of the $3 million World Chess Championship prize money Saturday by defeating Garry Kasparov, who has already won the title, in the 23rd game of their match. Karpov, playing white, forced his fellow Soviet grandmaster to withdraw in the 29th move after 3 hours, 50 minutes of play. That narrowed Kasparov's lead in their series to 12-11. The pair play their 24th and final game Monday. Kasparov, who needed only 12 points to keep his title, successfully defended it for the third time Wednesday by drawing with Karpov. The 0.5 points awarded for the draw brought Kasparov's point total to 12 against 10 for Karpov. But Karpov's victory Saturday night brought the score to 12-11, and the final game is vital for both men in terms of dividing up the prize money. If Karpov wins the last match, he assures himself of an equal $1.5-million share with his rival. If he loses or draws, he will have to settle for a $1.3 million share, while Kasparov pockets $1.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Plans Modest Inauguration Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo, who had scrapped plans for a fancy inauguration because of his state's tight budget, says he now plans a modest swearing-in ceremony. ``It won't be a big public ceremony,'' said the Democrat governor, who begins his third four-year term on New Year's Day. Last month, Cuomo canceled plans for a traditional public inauguration, a move he estimated would save the state about $70,000, and planned a private inauguration instead. Cuomo changed his mind last week, saying an inaugural ceremony is ``a nice tradition'' although not legally necessary since he was continuing in office. Cuomo and Lt. Gov. Stan Lundine will be sworn in Monday afternoon at the New York Court of Appeals building by Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, and the ceremony will cost nothing, the governor said. Earlier this month, Cuomo and the state Legislature approved a package of spending cuts to help eliminate a projected $1 billion deficit. The governor also is laying off 2,000 state workers by the end of the fiscal year on March 31. When he announced he was canceling the traditional inauguration, Cuomo said he wanted to ``avoid the expense it would necessarily entail.'' Past inaugural ceremonies included rousing gospel choirs and Indian chiefs in traditional dress.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Dissidents Vow To Topple Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi opposition factions say they want to overthrow President Saddam Hussein and form a transitional government to hold free elections and establish a democracy, newspapers reported Saturday. The conservative al-Anwar and pro-Syrian Ash-Sharq dailies published a statement by 15 oppositon groups saying the transitional government should be set up in Baghdad once Saddam has been toppled. It also said the state of emergency should be abolished, a general amnesty should be declared for all Saddam's opponents, and human rights should be guaranteed. The dissident groups have been meeting in Damascus, capital of Syria. The Syrians are Saddam's archrivals in the Arab world. They have sent about 19,000 troops to join the U.S.-dominated multinational force opposing Iraq. The crisis has accelerated moves by the disparate and often fractious Iraqi opposition groups to unite and exploit Saddam's international isolation. They have been seriously weakened by Saddam's ruthless elimination of opponents, his pervasive security apparatus, and their own divisions. All the groups are banned in Iraq. In recent months, they have made more determined moves to present a viable alternative to Saddam's one-man rule through the Baath Socialist Party. But analysts do not believe the dissident factions pose a significant threat to Saddam, even in the dire straits he now finds himself. Most analysts believe that the Iraqi army is the only organization capable of toppling him. The opposition groups in Damascus included the Iranian-backed Shiite Moslem ad-Dawa Islami movement, or Islamic Call, which has waged a bloody terrorist campaign against Baghdad for more than a decade. Other groups taking part were a splinter Baath faction, the Independent Arab Nationalists, the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan led by veteran guerrilla Jalal Talabani, and other Kurdish factions. The Kurdish groups, which have a history of feuding among themselves, have been fighting the Baghdad government off and on for decades seeking an independent Kurdish homeland. There are about 3.5 million Kurds in Iraq's 17 million population.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Denies Report It Might Withdraw From Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 3rd `Vice President...' to UPDATE with Quayle departure; pickup graf 4 `Iraq's information....' INSERTS 2 grafs to ADDS Germany asking for EC meeting; pickup graf 24 `An Air...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BAG1,DHR1-2
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Saturday denied reports that it is engaged in secret contacts with Washington to avert war and might withdraw from Kuwait before the United Nation's Jan. 15 deadline. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, meanwhile, held talks on a new effort by the world's non-aligned nations to defuse the buildup in the Persian Gulf. Vice President Dan Quayle left Washington late Saturday on a quick trip to Saudi Arabia to spend New Year's Day with American troops and to visit Saudi leaders and the exiled emir of Kuwait. Iraq's information minister, Latif Nussayif Jassim, denied a report by Radio Monte Carlo that secret U.S.-Iraqi contacts were under way, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The radio report quoted unidentified diplomatic sources in Egypt as saying Iraq was considering some ideas proposed by Washington. The radio said these include an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait in exchange for assurances that it will not be attacked by the U.S.-led multinational force, which is expected to total more than half a million troops by the end of January. ``These are ridiculous ideas and figments of the imagination,'' Jassim was quoted as saying. Independent Radio Monte Carlo, which has an Arabic-language service widely listened to in the Middle East, is generally reliable in its reporting on the Persian Gulf situation. A statement later Saturday by Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council called the report a ``sick interpretation (that) exists only in the minds of the planners of evil and their suspect circles.'' U.S. officials have also denied that secret talks are being held. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has sent an estimated 500,000 troops to southern Iraq and Kuwait since he seized the emirate on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money. The statement by his ruling council reaffirmed Iraq's determination to hold on to the conquered emiate despite the U.N. deadline to pullout by Jan. 15 or face possible attack. A political activist in Jordan said Saturday that Saddam has messaged King Fahd of Saudi Arabia warning that his country will be Iraq's second target after Israel if Saudi leaders continue to push for war. Azmi Khawaja, leader of the Marxist Popular Jordanian Democratic Unity Party, said Saddam spoke to him of the letter during a 90-minute meeting in Baghdad this week. Last week, Saddam threatened to attack Israel in the event of war. Aziz took a hard line in his discussions with Yugoslav Foreign Minister Budimir Loncar, who was in Baghdad on behalf of the 102-nation non-aligned movement, which Yugoslavia leads. Iraq's state news agency reported that Aziz repeated Iraqi demands to link a pullout of Kuwait with a resolution of the Arab-Israeli dispute. The United States has repeatedly rejected attempts to link the two issues, demanding Saddam's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Details of Loncar's initiative were not given. Previous attempts at mediation have failed but Loncar's new initiative had at least one difference: both Iraq and Kuwait belong to the non-aligned movement, which rejects any formal military alliances with East or West. Loncar was to meet Sunday with Saddam. Last month, he visited Iran, the United Arab Emirates, Syria and Jordan for talks on the crisis. Aziz told reporters there had been no breakthrough in the stalemate over fixing a date for direct U.S.-Iraqi talks. Iraq had invited Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit on Jan. 12, but the Bush administration says that is too close to the Jan. 15 deadline. Washington has said any Baker-Saddam meeting must take place before Thursday. In other developments: -Iraqi media reported that up to 300,000 paramilitary troops in the Kurdish region have been reactivated to shore up the country's northern border with Turkey, part of the anti-Iraq coalition. The Iraqi buildup at the Turkish border is believed to include at least eight divisions, including two armored divisions, or possibly more than 100,000 men, Asian diplomats in Baghdad said Saturday. Turkey has requested NATO send 42 jetfighters as a deterrent against Iraq, and Germany is considering taking part in the force. -In Bonn, Germany, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher proposed that his European Community colleagues convene a special meeting next week to discuss the gulf crisis, German radio reported Saturday. Westdeutscher Rundfunk radio said Genscher has suggested the meeting occur on Jan. 4. Further details were not immediately available. -An Air Force weather forecaster said the U.S. military isn't getting important data collected by Saudi Arabia, even as winter sandstorms and choppy seas pose new obstacles for U.S.-led forces. The forecaster, Capt. Judy Dickey, said that although the kingdom does supply some information, it does not share data on wind speed and direction, fearing that teletype reports would aid Iraq in launching a chemical or biological attack. -American medical experts say a U.S. plan to inoculate troops in the gulf against germ warfare agents could not possibly protect servicemen against all of the hundreds of microbes that could be used in a biological attack. Dr. Bradley Sack, a Johns Hopkins University expert on infectious diseases, said the troops would have to be vaccinated weeks or even months in advance for sufficient protection against disease. In Toulon, French chief of staff Gen. Maurice Schmitt said Saturday that his country's soldiers in the gulf or en route have been vaccinated for contagious diseases like typhus and cholera. British officials say they are also inoculating their forces. -A 66-year-old Swedish peace activist was hospitalized in Oman for a heart condition after U.S. forces on Wednesday intercepted the Iraqi ship she was on in the Arabian Sea. Omani Health Ministry officials said Margaret Andersson was on a cardiac monitor in a hospital Saturday after the U.S. Navy airlifted her from the freighter. The freighter was carrying sugar and other goods in violation of a U.N. embargo on Iraq. -In Tunis, Tunisia, 12 of the 15 Iraqi civil servants employed by the Arab League quit Saturday in protest of next week's transfer of the 21-nation organization's headquarters to Cairo. Egypt is one of the leading Arab countries opposed to Baghdad in the gulf crisis. On Saturday, it sent 1,000 more soldiers to Saudi Arabia to reinforce its 20,000-member force.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Trolley Operator Fails Alcohol Test After Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, `Another rider ...' to UPDATE with woman's identity.
DOC.TEXT: A 20-year transit veteran who operated a Boston trolley that crashed into another rail car had an alcohol level above the Massachusetts drunken driving limit, transit officials said Saturday. Investigators worked into the weekend to learn the circumstances of the Boston accident, which injured 33 people, and a New York subway fire, which injured 150 and claimed a second life Saturday. Both occurred underground Friday morning. New York Mayor David Dinkins said he expected city workers to have a report on his desk by Monday afternoon. He ordered the review amid charges that mistakes and confusion hampered rescue operations. Questions also arose about whether huge ventilation fans in the Brooklyn subway tunnel that were out of order could have drawn away smoke from the electrical fire. In Boston, federal safety officials began inspecting the trolleys involved. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority officials said the brakes and signals functioned properly, but the operator said he had trouble braking. ``There is no indication that we know of at this time that alcohol was used on the job,'' said Peter Dimond, an MBTA spokesman. He said officials believe the operator drank before starting his shift. Dimond said he could not release the exact alcohol test results for the 64-year-old MBTA worker, but said the operator exceeded the state's blood alcohol drunken driving limit, which is .10 percent. The driver, whose name was not released, has been suspended without pay. The driver was on the return leg of his first trip at 6:34 a.m. when the car he was steering crashed into the rear of another Green Line trolley at Arlington Station in the city's downtown district. Transit officials were trying to determine whether the operator involved in the crash was the one a passenger had called to complain about just a half hour earlier. ``We got a message that there was abusive language, that the driver was not behaving properly, but there was no indication that there was a safety risk,'' Dimond said. The Boston Herald reported that Tony Niederberger of Watertown telephoned MBTA police and told a fare collector that a driver was cursing and had sped through a curve, knocking passengers from their seats. The MBTA promised a prompt public hearing. ``We want to be fair to the operator. We want to be fair to the traveling public as well,'' Dimond said. The New York review will include recommendations on preventing further accidents and ensuring rescue efforts ``are performed in a timely and coordinated fashion,'' Dinkins said. Fire and transit authorities blamed melting slush for short-circuiting a transformer, which exploded and caused a smoky fire that stopped a Manhattan-bound train. Passenger Peter Hagen, 35, of Smithtown, N.Y., apparently suffered a heart attack and was pronounced dead Friday on arrival at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. Another rider, Dorene Blumenthal, 37, of Massapequa Park, N.Y., died early Saturday at the hospital, said nursing supervisor Fran Peszko.

Sylvia Lark, whose paintings hang in such prestigious institutions as the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, died Thursday of cancer. She was 43. Lark, a professor of art at the University of California, died at her Berkeley home. She won the 1991 Distinguished Teaching of Studio Art Award from the College Art Association. She was scheduled to receive the award at a presentation in February. Lark's paintings have been exhibited in more than 125 national and international group shows. In addition to the Metropolitan, Lark's abstracts are in the permanent collections in the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, the Oakland Museum, the Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco and the University Art Museum in Berkeley. Lark, a native of Buffalo, N.Y., served on the National Advisory Board of the Women's Caucus for the Arts from 1978 until 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Government Pardons Former Dictators, Terrorist Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with additional details, CORRECTS to show total of 12 people freed. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Two former dictators who led the 1970s ``dirty war'' against a leftist insurgency and a rebel leader whose movement inspired the repression were freed Saturday by government pardons. The onetime dictators, former army Gens. Jorge Videla and Roberto Viola, and Montonero guerrilla founder Mario Eduardo Firmenich, walked free for the first time since 1984. Videla and Viola were among 11 former officials, mostly generals convicted of torture and other rights abuses, who were pardoned under an order announced Thursday by President Carlos Menem. Menem, who last year freed 39 other generals and 64 terrorists, said Saturday's releases would ``definitely close a sad and black stage of Argentine history.'' The pardons, however, will reopen wounds for many Argentines. Recent polls have shown up to 80 percent of the population opposed freeing the men who symbolized a painful period in which thousands were spirited away by men in civilian clothing and never seen again. The army said its unconventional war in the late 1970s and early 1980s was the only kind possible to fight leftist insurgents. Human rights groups say up to 30,000 people died in a campaign of genocide. ``This is a very sad day for Argentina,'' said former President Raul Alfonsin, who pushed forward the bitter trials of the military regime after being elected in 1983. Menem succeeded him last year. Politicians, clergy and human rights activists planned to demonstrate Sunday across this South American nation of 31 million people. The others freed by Menem's announcement included dismissed Admiral Emilio Massera and former army chief of staff Carlos Suarez Mason, who was extradited from the United States in 1988 for a trial that never was held. Argentina's war began in the early 1970s, when leftists trying to topple the government unleashed a wave of assassinations, bombings, bank robberies and kidnappings for ransom. Firmenich boldly announced the existence of the Montoneros in June 1970 by kidnapping and executing former military president Pedro Aramburu. Growing unrest led Videla and Viola to stage the March 1976 coup that overthrew President Isabel Peron. Videla became president until 1981, when Viola took over for a year. The military stepped down in December 1983 after its disastrous defeat in the Falklands War with Britain. Officials have documented the disappearance of at least 8,960 people in the years after the 1976 coup. All are presumed to have been kidnapped and executed by the military. According to testimony in the trials, the military burned the bodies of some its victims, buried others in unmarked graves and tossed some from helicopters into the sea. Thousands of Argentine families spent years trying to find out what happened to loved ones. Some still don't know. Adolfo Perez Esquivel, winner of the 1980 Nobel Peace Prize, said the pardons ``signify the consecration of impunity for the authors of grave crimes against humanity.'' Menem, a former governor jailed for nearly five years by Videla, said he was ready to surrender the past and so should his countrymen in the interest of national reconciliation and political stability. The pending trials of ``dirty war'' officers sparked three army insurrections in recent years, and the imprisonment of Videla and the others was the justification for a fourth uprising, on Dec. 3. The government news agency Telam said Videla, Viola, Massera and retired Gen. Pablo Riccheri were released from Magdalena military prison, 62 miles south of Buenos Aires, and taken away in a helicopter. Firmenich was met outside Devoto prison in Buenos Aires by his lawyer and family, and whisked away by car. Suarez Mason and dismissed general Ramon Camps were released from a military hospital in the capital, Telam reported. The others who received pardons, including former economy minister Jose Martinez de Hoz, already had been freed. Two of the former officials, Norma Kennedy and Duilio Brunello, served prison terms for fraud charges unrelated to the ``dirty war.'' The pardon cleared a total of 12 men and women of pending charges, officials said, but since the decree has not been published it wasn't known if it permits those pardoned to hold public office again.

DOC.HEAD: Air National Guard Fighters Head For Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-four F-16 pilots left for Saudi Arabia Saturday, flying the first Air National Guard fighter jets deployed in the Persian Gulf crisis. Also Saturday, five Charleston-based warships, part of a 17-ship fleet headed for the Middle East, left port after heavy fog lifted. They had been scheduled to leave Friday. Pilots from the 169th Tactical Fighter Group took off from McEntire Air National Guard Base near Eastover. The 15-hour flight to Saudi Arabia - the unit's longest - will require at least 10 in-flight refuelings. More than 700 other members of the unit, mostly support crew, will follow during the next three weeks. The F-16s will fly 7,000 miles without a rest stop, said one pilot, Capt. Thorne Ambrose. ``No one in the squadron has ever flown that far at one shot, and each one of us is dealing with staying awake in our own way,'' he said. ``We will talk to each other a lot and some of us are taking CD players and Walkmans to pass the time. And, of course, we will be busy refueling.'' Two airborne fuel tankers accompanied the unit. The 169th is the first Air National Guard fighter unit in the nation and the largest South Carolina National Guard unit deployed for Operation Desert Shield. The F-16s are capable of air-to-air and air-to-ground combat and are commonly armed with AIM-9 missiles and a 20-mm machine gun. The guided-missile cruiser Richmond K. Turner, the guided-missile destroyer William V. Pratt, the guided-missile frigates Halyburton and Hawes and the ammunition ship Santa Barbara left the Charleston Naval Station Saturday. The ships, carrying about 1,500 sailors, are part of a 17-ship East Coast deployment. The United States began a massive military buildup in the region after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi troops to withdraw.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Announces New Pact With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped Cuba signed a new economic aid pact with the Soviet Union on Saturday. Cuba's official news agency said Soviet exports would be adjusted, but it gave no figures. Soviet officials have warned that the crisis in their own country would mean significant cuts in aid to Cuba, whose hard-line Communist government is increasingly at odds with the changing Soviet Union. Western experts say Cuba has received about $5 billion yearly in economic help and $1.5 billion in military aid for many of the past 30 years. The Prensa Latina agency, in a dispatch from Moscow, did not reveal detailed information about the aid agreement, which it said was signed after 10 days of talks. The agreement was reached by the Cuban foreign commerce minister, Ricardo Cabrisas, and the Soviet economic relations minister, Konstantin Katushev, the agency reported. ``Cuban sources considered the volumes of Soviet exports adjusted to the requirements of the country in the special period'' facing Cuba, said the agency, monitored in Mexico City. The ``special period'' refers to austerity measures adopted to confront Cuba's loss of its friends in Eastern Europe, the declining Soviet economy and increases in the price of oil, which Cuba must import. More and more goods are rationed in Cuba, Communist officials are being shipped off to do farm work in the countryside, and the leadership is promoting the use of bicycles to save gasoline. The agency said Cuba agreed to ship sugar, nickel, citrus, tobacco, alcoholic drinks, medications and biotechnology products to the Soviet Union. In return, Cuba will receive fuel, cereals, chemical and metal products, machinery and other goods, as well as continued technical and economic assistance. Foreign aid is to be considered by the Soviet parliament next month, and Soviet officials have suggested Cuba's aid may be cut. The Soviet Union wants its allies to pay in convertible currency at world prices starting Jan. 1. That would be a major blow to Cuba, which has long enjoyed subsidized Soviet exports in return for exports shipped at inflated prices.

DOC.HEAD: Light Tremor Reported in Washington State
DOC.TEXT: A light earthquake rattled an area in west-central Washington State late Saturday, the U.S. Geological Survey said. The agency said the tremor was centered about 30 miles east of Seattle and occurred at 6:21 p.m. PST. USGS earthquake monitors in Golden, Colo., said they recorded the tremor at a preliminary magnitude of 3.5 on the Richter scale. That is enough to cause slight damage. It was reported in the Snoqualmie and North Bend areas. Every increase of one number on the Richter scale means the ground motion is 10 times greater.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Gather for Centennial at Site of Wounded Knee Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to update with ceremony details, governor later entering ceremony, quotes. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `The riders ...' ^LaserPhoto RAP1
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of American Indians held a spiritual ceremony Saturday at this massacre site to commemorate the 100th anniversary of one of the saddest days in their history. About 100 horseback riders and several hundred other people watched as Indian spiritual leaders conducted the half-hour ceremony in sub-zero temperatures at the grave site of 146 Sioux Indians killed by U.S. Cavalry troops a century ago. ``To us, it was a massacre unjustified,'' said Mario Gonzalez, attorney for the Wounded Knee Survivors Association. ``The Army had no legal right to do what it did. We want Wounded Knee to be remembered, so it will never happen again.'' Russell Means, a leader of the militant American Indian Movement, blocked the entrance to the cemetery when Gov. George Mickelson showed up to pay his respects. The governor made no effort to get past him, but entered the cemetery later, said an aide, Gretchen Lord Anderson. ``It would be an insult (for Mickelson to enter) because we live in the racist state of South Dakota and he is the governor,'' Means said. ``He said I wasn't welcome,'' the governor said. ``He wants to make a mockery of all that has occurred in reconciliation.'' Mickelson later declared 1990 the Year of Reconciliation as part of state efforts to improve relations between Indians and non-Indians. The morning ceremony was conducted in temperatures of 21 below and a wind chill of 60 to 70 below zero. Riders who circled the cemetery rode past a spiritual leader holding up a can of burning sage. They waved their hands and eagle feathers at the smoke to purify themselves as others beat drums and sang traditional songs. The riders had retraced the 220-mile journey that Chief Big Foot and his band took before they were killed by cavalry troops at Wounded Knee. The riders endured snow and sub-zero wind chills during part of their two-week ride. ``I think it (weather) was probably appropriate during this ride because Indian people believe that when they make a pledge and commitment that suffering is part of that pledge and commitment,'' said Colorado Congressman Dan Night Horse Campbell, an Indian. The crowd later went to a school seven miles away for other ceremonies at which Mickelson and others spoke. The names of those who died at Wounded Knee were read. ``The massacre at Wounded Knee is one of many dark moments in American history,'' Mickelson said. Mickelson said he was ``pledging my own commitment to learn from our past in order to build a future for all South Dakotans regardless of race or culture.'' The governor said he will keep trying to persuade federal officials to create a national monument at Wounded Knee. The site should be preserved according to the wishes of Wounded Knee descendants, he said. Hundreds of Sioux men, women and children were killed b U.S. cavalry soldiers at Wounded Knee in an event that some historians said signified the end of the Indian wars. On Friday, nearly 300 horseback riders and others on foot endured wind-chill temperatures as low as 50 degrees below zero Friday on their way to the ceremony. The riders assembled their horses in a circle at the massacre site Friday and prayed for peace within the Sioux Nation and throughout the world. Two former American Indian Movement leaders, Means and Dennis Banks, joined the riders last week. Some riders said they were bothered by the participation of activists associated with the armed takeover of Wounded Knee in 1973, which led to two deaths. After Sioux leader Sitting Bull was killed in December 1890, Big Foot led a band of about 400 Sioux from central South Dakota to seek refuge at the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in southwestern South Dakota. Accounts differ as to who fired first and how many died when the cavalry intercepted the Sioux. The federal government says about 150 Indians died; the Sioux say as many as 400 were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Company Convicted of Homicide Charges in Workers' Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A construction company was found guilty of homicide in the deaths of two workers killed in a methane gas explosion at a sewer excavation site. Milwaukee County Circuit Court jurors deliberated about 4{ hours Friday before finding S.A. Healy Co. of McCook, Ill., guilty of two counts of homicide by reckless conduct in the deaths of Tony Bell, 25, of Sturgeon Bay, Wis., and Rick Sochacki, 34, of South Holland, Ill. Also killed in the Nov. 10, 1988, explosion was project superintendent Ron Kohne, 49, of Big Sandy, Tenn. The men died in a tunnel that is part of the Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage Commission's $2 billion improvement project. Miwaukee County District Attorney E. Michael McCann announced the state charges at the same time federal prosecutors revealed a 12-count indictment charging the company with criminal violations of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. The company was convicted of failing to provide and maintain a sufficient ventilation system and proper electrical equipment, of providing inadequate safety instruction to employees, and of failing to de-energize electrical power in the area where high levels of methane gas were detected. Testimony at a coroner's inquest last December indicated the tunnel had been cleared of workers the day the blast occurred because of high methane levels. The victims were returning to check the tunnel when the gas exploded. Healy attorney David Cannon denied the company was careless. Kohne wouldn't have entered the tunnel if he had thought there was a hazard, he argued. Project manager Patrick Doig, a mining engineer, testified that the tunnel's ventilation system was adequate. Cannon said engineering consultants hadn't encouraged Healy to install extra safety measures. Healy faces a fine of $10,000 on each count. After the verdict, lawyers said they couldn't comment because civil suits are pending. A U.S. District Court trial is scheduled Jan. 22 the 12 misdemeanor counts, which carry a cumulative maximum penalty of $6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Power Outage Darkens National Airport
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0583 to fix cycle designator
DOC.TEXT: A power outage darkened National Airport outside the nation's capital for four hours Saturday and airline workers reverted to pre-computer era methods to get travelers on their way. Security workers checked luggage by hand as X-ray machines went dark and ticket agents found themselves working without benefit of the computer reservation systems normally used. There were some delays at the airport, located just across the Potomac River from Washington, and a few flights were canceled. But a backup generator provided enough emergency power to keep air operations going. The airport's acting manager, Ronald Strange, said all airline computer reservation systems had been affected as well as baggage claim facilities. Airport personnel used flashlights to guide passengers through darkened corridors and down stairways. No injuries were reported. The first of two power lines that feed the airport blew at 11:53 a.m., causing some areas to lose power. The system automatically restored power to those areas by shifting the entire burden to the remaining line. Virginia Power officials said, however, that a few minutes after noon someone in the airport inadvertently threw a switch that blew the other circuit. The power failure lasted until about 4 p.m., officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Incoming Washington Mayor Calls for $250 Million Spending Cut
DOC.TEXT: Mayor-elect Sharon Pratt Dixon is calling on aides to draft plans for $250 million in spending cuts to fight this city's burgeoning budget deficit without raising taxes, her financial advisers say. Dixon, who takes her oath of office Wednesday, promised in her campaign last fall that if elected she would not call for a tax increase. Aides said Dixon, who succeeds outgoing Mayor Marion Barry, hopes to lay the groundwork for an increase in federal aid to the city by showing Congress and the White House she will back tough spending cuts. ``She's going to try to show her bona fides before she asks for help,'' top financial adviser Franklin D. Raines said. What Dixon wants increased is the $435 million federal payment that is sent annually to the District of Columbia government to help with the cost of running the city. The federal payment, which has not increased in five years, is made in lieu of local taxes. Raines warned Dixon in a Dec. 21 memo that the deficit for the fiscal year ending next Sept. 30 could reach $275 million to $300 million. Dixon has asked aides to find budget cuts totaling about $250 million, more than 6 percent of the city's $3.8 billion operating budget. The incoming mayor said last week she expects the federal government to substantially increase the annual payment. Many local politicians have been claiming that the federal government has been treating the city unfairly. Dixon said in her campaign that she could solve the budget problem by eliminating waste and inefficiency and cutting 2,000 of the 48,000 city workers. She said she did not believe it would require cuts in programs and services. But Dixon may reconsider her support of pay raises for city workers, Raines indicated. The city has planned for raises for teachers, police officers and other city workers totaling roughly $60 million to $80 million during the current fiscal year.

The Texas House speaker was indicted on charges he accepted $5,000 from a law firm and didn't disclose it, joining legislative leaders in the two other most populous states under an ethical cloud. House speakers in New York and California also are under scrutiny as they prepare for new legislative sessions. The investigation in Texas also involves other legislators. A Travis County grand jury returned indictments on two misdemeanor charges Friday against Gib Lewis, alleging he solicited and received a gift from the San Antonio-based law firm of Heard Goggan Blair & Williams, then failed to report it. Despite the charges, Lewis' lawyer said the lawmaker would seek an unprecedented fifth term as House speaker. Lewis has denied the allegations and his lawyer said he'd plead innocent to the charges. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Authorities blamed the first snowstorm of the season for an electrical fire that trapped four rush-hour trains in a smoke-filled subway tunnel, killing one person and injuring more than 150 others. In Boston, authorities investigating a trolley accident that injured 33 people Friday said tests showed the trolley driver had high levels of alcohol in his system. It was the second rail accident this month in the city's Back Bay section. The driver of the trolley, which rammed a streetcar that was unloading passengers, blamed faulty brakes for the collision, officials said. But investigators ruled that out as a possible cause, said Peter Dimond, spokesman for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The fire Friday morning in New York filled trains with smoke in a subway tunnel linking Manhattan and Brooklyn. Fire and transit officials said melting snow from a 7-inch snowfall overnight apparently caused an electrical short-circuit. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Vice President Dn Quayle doesn't abide discrimination at golf clubs, his office says, but he still plays at one of the most exclusive all-male courses near the capital as an honorary member. Quayle on Friday canceled a second round of golf at the all-white Cypress Point golf club near Monterey, Calif., after he learned the facility was mired in a racial controversy, said his press secretary, David Beckwith. He had played there Thursday, unaware, Beckwith said, that the club was ruled ineligible for its share of the 1991 AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am tournament next month because it has no black members. Quayle was ``unwilling to leave any impression that he condones any form of discrimination,'' so he left California and returned to Vail, Colo., where he had been on a skiing vacation, Beckwith said. But the spokesman said he could not explain why Quayle is an honorary member of the Burning Tree Club in suburban Bethesda, Md., which bars women from its course. ---= SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - California stopped telling casual marijuana users ``smoke a joint, go to jail'' 15 years ago. But the federal government's new version - ``smoke a joint, lose your driver's license'' - promises to rekindle debate over the state's pot law. A little-noted amendment to a new federal highway funding law seeks to use federal funding as a weapon against liberal state drug laws. It would particularly affect California and New York because of those states' relatively liberal marijuana laws and large amounts of federal funding. The federal law calls for every state to pass a law in 1991-92 requiring a six-month driver license suspension for anyone convicted of violating any drug law, including possession of marijuana for personal use. States that refuse could lose 5 percent of their federal highway aid in the 12 months starting Oct. 1, 1993. That would be $60 million at current levels of aid to California, said the amendment's sponsor, Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y. The amendment passed in July. Leaders of California's Democratic-controlled Legislature chafed at the federal interference, but Gov.-elect Pete Wilson, a Republican, agrees that the state's drug laws are too lenient. Solomon's amendment lets a state avoid a monetary penalty only if both the Legislature and the governor oppose the requirement of license suspensions.

DOC.HEAD: 1990: A Lousy Year By Any Measure in Business
DOC.TEXT: Just how bad a year was it for business? Ask Michael Milken. Or Donald Trump. Or Citicorp. By almost anyone's standard, 1990 failed to measure up. For the start of a new decade, the year was particularly disappointing. It was a year of undoing and retreat, of dashed hopes and unfulfilled promises. Fortunes were lost. Reputations were damaged. Big deals fell apart. The economy slid into decline. The stock market hit a record high and then tumbled downhill. Car sales slumped, and consumers spent sparingly for Christmas. Homebuilding stalled, and real estate values in many parts of the country plummeted. The buyouts of the '80s gave way to the bankruptcies of the '90s as heavy debts pushed enterprises big and small to the brink of collapse. Banks were left holding the bag for much of the mess, having loaned billions for souring real estate deals and corporate takeovers. The news turned bad even before Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, but the ensuing crisis in the Persian Gulf added a ``war premium'' to oil prices that drove up prices at the gasoline pump and stoked the embers of inflation. It all inspired Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan to pronounce ``a meaningful downturn'' in the economy near year's end, although he stopped short of using the ``R'' word to proclaim an official recession. The chairman of one hard-hit Wall Street firm was more blunt in his assessment of the 1990 environment. ``Business stinks,'' George Ball of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said in a November memo to his staff.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Slip-Sliding Into Recession
DOC.TEXT: The government's regular monthly statistics on the economy became a litany of woe in the waning weeks of the year. Unemployment reached 5.9 percent in November, a three-year high. The index of leading economic indicators signaled the beginning of a recession with five consecutive monthly declines beginning in July. As construction slowed, sales of new homes dipped to their lowest level since the last recession eight years ago. Manufacturing also languished. Just this past week, orders for durable goods - items that last more than three years - were reported off by 10.5 percent in November. The drop was viewed by some economists as confirmation of a deepening recession. The lone break in the chain of bad news was a moderate inflation report for November, which provided an opening for the Federal Reserve to try to turn things around. The Fed, which can influence the fate of the economy by regulating the nation's money supply, had been holding a tight rein on credit to keep inflation under control. When inflation abated - despite the lingering effects of the gulf crisis - the Fed took a dramatic step to ease credit by lowering its lending rate to banks. The drop in the discount rate, by a half point to 6.5 percent, was the first cut in the rate in more than four years.
DOC.HEAD: BANKS: Too Weak to Respond to the Medicine
DOC.TEXT: The medicine might have worked wonders under normal circumstances. But the nation's banks were too weak to respond to the dose of easier credit. Only a handful of banks lowered their prime lending rates to business customers after the Fed's December move. The biggest banks were busy shoring up their own finances. On the same day the discount rate was cut, Citicorp, the nation's largest bank, said it would set aside $340 million to cover bad loans and cut up to 8,000 jobs. Many banks were shaky, and the cost of insuring bank deposits against failures was skyrocketing. William Seidman, head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said the insurance fund would lose $9 billion through 1991, leaving just $4 billion to guarantee $2 trillion in deposits. The hard times were expected to prompt a wave of consolidation in the industry that would leave fewer, stronger banks.
DOC.HEAD: MARKETS: A Record Run Turns South
DOC.TEXT: One of the most depressing experiences of the year for shareholders was watching the stock market's steady decline from the exhilarating heights of a record close in July, a quarter point shy of the 3,000 mark on the Dow Jones industrial average. The fall was precipitated, not by Saddam Hussein, but by a rash of poor corporate earnings reports that preceded the Kuwait invasion. The gulf crisis added oil price worries to the mix, and corporate earnings looked even bleaker by the third quarter. Most of the action in the financial markets shifted to the oil pits, where barrels of crude for future delivery are traded. Frenzied speculation nearly doubled the price of a barrel of oil to more than $40 by October, before it slid back under $30 toward year's end. The conventional wisdom held that the world was awash in oil, but the supply side of the equation mattered little, as long as the threat of a shooting war in the Middle East loomed.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: Let's Not Make a Deal
DOC.TEXT: One missing ingredient in the markets was merger mania. It departed with the '80s. Some big deals survived into the new decade, but they were few and far between. With bank credit drying up and the market for junk bonds exhausted, not much American money could be raised for takeover wars. The biggest play was launched from Japan. Cash-rich Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. cut a $7.4 billion deal to buy entertainment giant MCA Inc. Other deals were driven by necessity. American Telephone & Telegraph Co., anxious to expand its computer business, tried to reach out and grab NCR Corp. in a deal worth more than $6 billion. NCR rejected the proposal and Ma Bell took its case directly to the shareholders in the form of a tender offer. One high-profile deal fell apart, not for lack of financing but for lack of a star player. Walt Disney Co. dropped its plans to purchase Henson Associates Inc., home of the Muppets, following the death of creative genius Jim Henson. In the airline business, deals became a way of life, but it was a life of quiet desperation for some. Rising fuel prices and sluggish traffic forced the weak to sell assets to the strong. Pan Am Corp. peddled London routes to United Airlines, and Trans World Airlines sold its London business to American Airlines. TWA then made an offer to buy Pan Am. Meanwhile, Continental Airlines joined sister carrier Eastern Airlines in bankruptcy court. Frank Lorenzo, who had paired these carriers in the largest airline empire ever, disappeared almost entirely from the scene, giving way to new regimes at Eastern and Continental.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Milken, Trump Make Biggest Headlines
DOC.TEXT: In a year of fading fortunes, the business anti-hero rated the largest headlines. Michael Milken and Donald Trump, rising stars of the '80s, became even more famous as fallen angels in the '90s. Milken, who popularized the use of debt to bankroll big corporate deals, pleaded guilty to securities fraud charges, agreed to pay fines and restitution of $600 million, and was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Drexel Burnham Lambert, the securities firm he rode to greatness, filed for protection from creditors in bankruptcy court. Trump, who used debt like steroids to pump up his casino and real estate empire, tumbled with the economy and spent much of the year fending off his creditors. Along the way, another costly venture came unraveled: his marriage. The mighty-turned-miserable had plenty of company. For the first time ever, the minimumm amount of money needed to make Forbes magazine's list of the 400 richest Americans went down. Anyone with $260 million still qualified.

DOC.HEAD: Matsushita Closes MCA Deal
DOC.TEXT: Japan's largest electrical company on Saturday closed its $6.6 billion purchase of entertainment colossus MCA Inc., completing the largest Japanese acquisition of an American firm. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. acquired about 77.7 million shares of MCA stock at $66 per share, Matsushita said in a statement. Its acquisitions amount to about 97 percent f outstanding MCA shares. The buyout matches Matsushita's electronics products with MCA's movie and music empire. MCA runs Universal Studios, maker of such films as ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestial,'' and ``Jaws.'' The firm holds recording contracts with such artists as Guns N' Roses and Elton John and produces the television programs ``Murder, She Wrote'' and ``Major Dad.'' Matsushita products are marketed in the United States through such brand names as Panasonic, Technics and Quasar. MCA will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Matsushita and all remaining MCA stockholders will be entitled to receive $66 in cash for each share still held, the statement said. Legal obstacles were removed Friday, when a federal judge in Los Angeles rejected a bid by MCA shareholders seeking to block the sale. The lawsuit contended that MCA Chairman Lew Wasserman was violating Securities and Exchange Commission rules by receiving tax-free stock transfers as part of the deal. Wasserman alone is to receive a new preferred Matsushita stock that saves him $100 million in capital gains taxes and additional estate taxes. U.S. District Judge Manuel Real did not dismiss the lawsuit, but said there was insufficient evidence presented to block the transaction. In a separate case, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia denied a last-minute motion in an antitrust suit filed by Go-Video Inc., maker of dual-deck VCRs.
